headlines: ["Thomas Serre announces limited availability during sabbatical and provides contact instructions"]
anchors: ["urgent matters text message", "prospective graduate students applications", "grant-related matters contact", "CCV-related matters subject line", "on sabbatical until September 1, 2025"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Serre, Thomas" <thomas_serre@brown.edu>
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-05-03T18:47:59-07:00
Subject: Out of Office: On Sabbatical Until September 1, 2025 Re: ONR Topic 14: Evaluation and Monitoring of Large-Scale Generative AI.

Hello,
Thank you for your email. I am currently on sabbatical until September 1, 2025, and will be largely unavailable during this period.
  * **Urgent matters** : Please send me a text message on my cell.
  * **CCV-related matters** : Please resend your email with "CCV" included in the subject line.
  * **Grant-related matters** : Please reach out to CLPSgrants@Brown.edu.
  * **Prospective graduate students:** I will be accepting graduate students. I recommend you apply to the graduate program in Cognitive Science or Computer Science. You may also apply to the graduate program in Neuroscience.
  * For all other inquiries, please resend your email after September 1, 2025, and I will respond as soon as possible upon my return.


Thank you for your understanding.
Best regards,  
Thomas
  
  
\--   

\--Thomas Serre
\--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Brown University | Carney Institute for Brain Science   
Thomas J. Watson, Sr. Professor of Science  

Departments of Cognitive & Psychological Sciences and Computer Science  

Faculty Director, Center for Computation & Visualization   

Associate Director, Center for Computational Brain Science
ANR-3IA Artificial and Natural Intelligence Toulouse Institute  

T: +1 401-863-1148 | [serre-lab.clps.brown.edu  
  
](http://serre-lab.clps.brown.edu)

Nancy
________________________________
From: Nancy Koppelman <koppelmn@hotmail.com>
Sent: Thursday, January 30, 2025 3:11:37 PM
To: James Russell <russelldeep@gmail.com>; Poznansky, Mark C.,MD, PhD <Mark_Poznansky@dfci.harvard.edu>
Cc: Sarah Livingston <sarah@academicengagement.org>; yag@gonch.name <yag@gonch.name>; davigan@bidmc.harvard.edu <davigan@bidmc.harvard.edu>; lahav.galit@gmail.com <lahav.galit@gmail.com>; mhoutchens@bhw.harvard.edu <mhoutchens@bhw.harvard.edu>; dan_shoag@hks.harvard.edu <dan_shoag@hks.harvard.edu>; jfried@law.harvard.edu <jfried@law.harvard.edu>; gilbert@wjh.harvard.edu <gilbert@wjh.harvard.edu>; dstern@fas.harvard.edu <dstern@fas.harvard.edu>; gabriel.kreiman@childrens.harvard.edu <gabriel.kreiman@childrens.harvard.edu>; carol.ehrlich@gmail.com <carol.ehrlich@gmail.com>; dotan_greenvald@fas.harvard.edu <dotan_greenvald@fas.harvard.edu>; wisse@fas.harvard.edu <wisse@fas.harvard.edu>; miribhalpern@gmail.com <miribhalpern@gmail.com>; gblum@law.harvard.edu <gblum@law.harvard.edu>; jlevenson@hds.harvard.edu <jlevenson@hds.harvard.edu>; rebar@channing.harvard.edu <rebar@channing.harvard.edu>; pinker@wjh.harvard.edu <pinker@wjh.harvard.edu>; stuart_schreiber@harvard.edu <stuart_schreiber@harvard.edu>; steve_kelman@hks.harvard.edu <steve_kelman@hks.harvard.edu>; jhamburg@fas.harvard.edu <jhamburg@fas.harvard.edu>; bargill@law.harvard.edu <bargill@law.harvard.edu>; eleekes@gmail.com <eleekes@gmail.com>; Sadie Weintraub <sadie@academicengagement.org>
Subject: Re: AEN is coming to Harvard

Greetings everyone,

Thanks, Mark, for asking about what kind of support is needed.  My sense from the SEAS staff is that my presentation will be better received if there are one or two people in the audience who are also affiliated with the AEN.  I have been keeping abreast of what's going on at Harvard, and my talk is definitely a step in the right direction.  If any of you are able to join me, I would be most grateful, and my hosts will have all the more reason to suggest bringing the AEN to speak at other schools on campus.  Please contact me directly if you are able to connect with me, and thanks so much.

Nancy

Nancy Koppelman
The Evergreen State College

Faculty Consultant for Special Projects
Academic Engagement Network

________________________________
From: James Russell <russelldeep@gmail.com>

Subject: AEN is coming to Harvard



        External Email - Use Caution

Dear Harvard AEN faculty members,



I have a request for support. An opportunity to show up for AEN and our mission to fight antisemitism on Harvard’s campus. Next month our Administrator Engagement consultant, Dr. Nancy Koppelman, is leading a session for the Harvard School of Engineering and Applied Sciences “Jewish Identity and Antisemitism on Campus.” This program is on 2/25, we are still confirming the time but we think it’s 1:00-3:00.



Nancy’s hosts at Harvard SEAS have explicitly told us that they want AEN members to attend the program. I would like to secure a volunteer to speak with Nancy ahead of the program and to get RSVPs from whomever is available to attend.



Please be in touch as soon as you can.



Thank you so much!

Sarah

Sarah Livingston, MA
Director of Member Engagement

Academic Engagement Network

headlines: ["Automatic reply indicating sabbatical and interim contact instructions"]
anchors: ["urgent matters via text message", "grant-related matters contact", "CCV in subject line", "prospective graduate students programs", "on sabbatical until September 1, 2025"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Serre, Thomas" <thomas_serre@brown.edu>
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-05-22T07:36:53-07:00
Subject: Out of Office: On Sabbatical Until September 1, 2025 Re: meeting

Hello,
Thank you for your email. I am currently on sabbatical until September 1, 2025, and will be largely unavailable during this period.
  * **Urgent matters** : Please send me a text message on my cell.
  * **CCV-related matters** : Please resend your email with "CCV" included in the subject line.
  * **Grant-related matters** : Please reach out to CLPSgrants@Brown.edu.
  * **Prospective graduate students:** I will be accepting graduate students. I recommend you apply to the graduate program in Cognitive Science or Computer Science. You may also apply to the graduate program in Neuroscience.
  * For all other inquiries, please resend your email after September 1, 2025, and I will respond as soon as possible upon my return.


Thank you for your understanding.
Best regards,  
Thomas
  
  
\--   

\--Thomas Serre
\--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Brown University | Carney Institute for Brain Science   
Thomas J. Watson, Sr. Professor of Science  

Departments of Cognitive & Psychological Sciences and Computer Science  

Faculty Director, Center for Computation & Visualization   

Associate Director, Center for Computational Brain Science
ANR-3IA Artificial and Natural Intelligence Toulouse Institute  

T: +1 401-863-1148 | [serre-lab.clps.brown.edu  
  
](http://serre-lab.clps.brown.edu)

headlines: ["Greg shares Transformer Dynamics manuscript for feedback"]

full_content:
Message 1
From: Grigori Guitchounts <g.guitchounts@gmail.com>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-01-31T16:50:22-05:00
Subject: Transformer Dynamics paper

Dear Gabriel,

I hope you're doing well! If you recall, back in the fall we talked about
some preliminary exploration I'd done into treating the transformer
residual stream as a dynamical system. Jesseba and I have done a bit more
on this since then and wanted to share our manuscript with you. If you have
any time and are interested, we'd love to hear your thoughts on this.

All the best,
Greg

---

headlines: ["Announce NOON Seminar by Zhaoping Li on vision theory and experiments", "Schedule 1:1 meeting between Gabriel Kreiman and Zhaoping Li"]
topics: ["Visit of Zhaoping Li and associated meetings and seminar"]
people: ["Aravi Samuel", "Blum, Kenneth I. <kenneth_blum@harvard.edu>", "I", "Zhaoping Li", "Venki Murthy", "SueYeon Chung"]
anchors: ["1:1 meeting", "NOON Seminar", "looking and seeing", "Monday 10 November", "vision framework", "11:00", "NW 169", "primary visual cortex", "seminar abstract"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Blum, Kenneth I." <kenneth_blum@harvard.edu>
To: 
  - Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
  - Samuel, Aravinthan <samuel@physics.harvard.edu>
  - SueYeon Chung <sueyeonchung@g.harvard.edu>
  - Murthy, Venkatesh <vnmurthy@fas.harvard.edu>
Time: 2025-11-06T17:57:03+00:00
Subject: Your 1:1 meeting with Zhaoping Li on Mon 10 Nov

Thank you for signing up to meet with Zhaoping during her visit this coming Monday. Please check the information below and let me know if you need to make any changes.


Zhaoping Li

Monday 10 November



11:00

Gabriel Kreiman (NW 169)

NOON Seminar

Seminar (NW 425) introduced by Kenny Blum

1:30

Aravi Samuel (NW 257)

2:15

Lunch

3:30

SueYeon Chung (NW 195.05)

4:15

Venki Murthy (Biolabs 4027)



Title: Formulating and understanding vision: progress in theory and experiments

Abstract: Using our own brains to study our brains is extraordinary. In vision --- the dominant primate sense --- this makes us blind to our own blindness, leading us astray in asking theoretical questions. Centuries of work, including contributions from Kepler through Newton to Maxwell, laid foundation for understanding retina, mainly as an optical sampling device of the environment. Then, within just a decade (1950s - 60s), electrophysiological recordings leapt from retinal neurons to those in primary visual cortex (V1), revealing how optical signals are transformed to signals in individual neurons. Yet progress beyond V1 has been markedly slower than the leap from retina to V1.

What, then, is vision as it advances from retina to mind?   A suitable formulation must recognize the brain's information processing (attentional) bottleneck, which admits a tiny fraction of retinal visual input for deeper processing. A fresh formulation (Zhaoping 2014, 2019) posits vision as looking and seeing: looking --- mainly by shifting gaze --- selects information for entry into the bottleneck, while seeing recognizes or infers object properties from what is selected. Since we are blind to non-selected inputs, understanding looking --- which often occurs before and even without seeing --- is essential to understanding vision as a whole.

This formulation generates falsifiable predictions, tested experimentally in psychology and neuroscience. Discoveries include a functional role of V1 in exogenously guiding gaze shifts, the involvement of neural circuits within and beyond V1, and new visual illusions in the process of seeing (Zhaoping 2025). These advances yield uncanny insights into our vision and mind. This framework can be extended to understand senses and minds of other animal species, e.g.,  rodents, fish, birds, bats, insects, many dominantly use a non-visual sense to "see" their world (Zhaoping 2023).


References:
Zhaoping, L. (2014) Understanding vision: theory, models, and data, Oxford University Press.
Zhaoping, L. (2019) A new framework for understanding vision from the perspective of the primary visual cortex. Current Opinion in Neurobiology, volume 58, page 1-10.
Zhaoping, L. (2023) Peripheral and central sensation: Multisensory orienting and recognition across species, Trends for Cognitive Sciences, Vol 27, issue 6, page 539-552.
Zhaoping, L. (2025) Testing the top-down feedback in the central visual field using the reversed depth illusion, iScience, Volume 28, Issue 4, 112223.


---
**Monday 10 November** |     
11:00 |  Gabriel Kreiman (NW 169)  
NOON Seminar  |  Seminar (NW 425) introduced by Kenny Blum  
1:30  |  Aravi Samuel (NW 257)  
2:15 |  Lunch  
3:30 |  SueYeon Chung (NW 195.05)  
4:15 |  Venki Murthy (Biolabs 4027)  
[...]

full_content:
Message 1
From: Bertha Zhang - MDPI <bertha.zhang@mdpi.com>
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-08-06T16:52:00+02:00
Subject: Call for Paper: [Brain Sciences] (IF: 2.8, ISSN: 2076-3425)— Special Issue "Brain Boosting: Recent Advances in Neurostimulation on Cognitive Functions and Behavioral Performance"

Dear Dr. Kreiman,

The open access journal Brain Sciences (ISSN 2076-3425, IF 2.8) is pleased to announce a new Special Issue entitled "Brain Boosting: Recent Advances in Neurostimulation on Cognitive Functions and Behavioral Performance". The submission deadline is 20 January 2026 and papers may be submitted immediately or at any point until 20 January 2026, as papers will be published on an ongoing basis. For more information on this Special Issue and submission guidelines, please visit the following page: https://www.mdpi.com/si/brainsci/5AQ5U7MNPU.

MDPI offers professional article preparation services (language and figure editing) completed in just 1 day: https://www.mdpi.com/authors/english.

We also invite you to post an early version of your paper on our free preprint platform, Preprints, allowing you to receive feedback from your peers and make your early results citable. For more information or to submit your preprint, visit https://www.preprints.org/about#works.

Please submit your decision on the invitation here http://susy.mdpi.com/special_issue/backend_cfp_decision/222040/Z2tyZWltYW5AZ21haWwuY29t/5e76a100e7ba86e9ad62bcd43f24510d34422f7c9bf2edb0ee12c6dbc18401e1.

Kind regards,

Bertha Zhang
Special Issue Editor

Brain Sciences is fully open access. Manuscripts are peer-reviewed and a first decision provided to authors approximately 16.24 days after submission. An Article Processing Charge (APC) of 2200 CHF currently applies to all papers accepted after peer review. You may be entitled to a discount if you have previously received a discount code from Editorial Office or if your institution is a participating member in MDPI’s Institutional Open Access Program (IOAP). For more information, please visit: http://www.mdpi.com/about/ioap.

To submit to the journal click here: http://susy.mdpi.com/user/manuscripts/upload?journal=brainsci.

4052 Basel
Switzerland

The information contained in this message is confidential and intended solely for the use of the individual or entity to whom they are addressed. headlines: ["Call for papers and deadline extension for HHAI 2025 conference"]
anchors: ["full papers", "call for papers", "working papers", "deadline extension", "double-blind reviewing"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Chiara Natali <c.natali6@campus.unimib.it>
To: EUCog General News <eucog-general-news@googlegroups.com>
Time: 2025-01-15T04:51:37-08:00
Subject: [EUCog News] [CFP] [Deadline Extension] HHAI 2025 - Hybrid
 Human-Artificial Intelligence (June 9-13, 2025, Pisa, Italy)

(Apologies if you receive multiple copies of this CfP)


---------------------------------------------------------------------

CALL FOR PAPERS


HHAI 2025 - Hybrid Human-Artificial Intelligence

https://hhai-conference.org/2025/

June 9–13, 2025, Pisa, Italy 


Abstract submission: January 24th, 2025 (Extended)

Paper submission: January 31th, 2025 (Extended)


Submission link: https://easychair.org/my/conference?conf=hhai2025

---------------------------------------------------------------------


Hybrid Human-Artificial Intelligence (HHAI) is an international conference 
series that focuses on the study of Artificial Intelligence systems that 
cooperate synergistically, proactively and purposefully with humans, 
amplifying instead of replacing human intelligence. HHAI aims for AI 
systems that work together with humans, emphasizing the need for adaptive, 
collaborative, responsible, interactive and human-centered intelligent 
systems. HHAI systems leverage human strengths and compensate for human 
weaknesses, while taking into account social, ethical and legal 
considerations.


HHAI 2025 will be held on June 9–13, 2025, in Pisa, Italy, and is the 
fourth conference in the series. The HHAI field is driven by developments 
in AI, but it also requires fundamentally new approaches and solutions. 
Thus, we encourage collaborations across research domains such as AI, HCI, 
cognitive and social sciences, philosophy and ethics, complex systems, and 
others. In this fourth international conference, we invite scholars from 
these fields to submit their best original – new as well as in progress – 
works, and visionary ideas on Hybrid Human-Artificial Intelligence.


**Join the HHAI community and keep up with the news:**


Website: https://hhai-conference.org/2025/

Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/company/hhai-conference/

X: https://x.com/hhai_conference

Mastodon: https://sigmoid.social/@hhai


IMPORTANT DATES


Abstract submission: January 24th, 2025 (Extended)

Paper submission: January 31th, 2025 (Extended)

Acceptance notification: March 16th, 2025

Camera-ready version: April 13th, 2025 

Conference: June 9-13, 2025


LOCATION


HHAI 2025 will be an in-person, single-track conference organized in Pisa, 
Italy. Workshops and tutorials (9-10 June) will be held at the University 
of Pisa and Scuola Normale Superiore in Pisa, Italy. The main conference 
(11-13 June) will be held at CNR. 


TOPICS


We invite research on different challenges in Hybrid Human-Artificial 
Intelligence. The following list of topics is illustrative, not exhaustive:


- Human-AI interaction, interpretation and collaboration

- Adaptive human-AI co-learning and co-creation

- Learning, reasoning and planning with humans and machines in the loop

- User modeling and personalisation

- Integration of learning and reasoning

- Transparent, explainable, and accountable AI

- Fair, ethical, responsible, and trustworthy AI

- Societal awareness of AI

- Multimodal machine perception of real-world settings

- Social signal processing

- Representations learning for Communicative or Collaborative AI

- Symbolic representations for human-centric AI

- Human-AI Coevolution

- Foundation models and humans

- Human cognition-aware AI

- Decentralized human-AI systems

- Reliability and robustness in human-AI systems

- Applications of hybrid human-AI intelligence


We welcome contributions about all types of technology, from robots and 
conversational agents to multi-agent systems and machine learning models.


PAPER TYPES


In this conference, we wish to stimulate the exchange of novel ideas and 
interdisciplinary perspectives. To do this, we will accept three different 
types of papers:


- Full papers present original, impactful work (12 pages excluding 
references)

- Blue sky papers present visionary ideas to stimulate the research 
community (8 pages excluding references)

- Working papers present work in progress (8 pages excluding references)


Accepted full papers and Blue sky papers will be published in the 
Proceedings of the Fourth International Conference on Hybrid Human-Machine 
Intelligence, in the Frontiers of AI series by IOS Press. Working papers 
can be included in these proceedings, unless the authors request the paper 
to remain unpublished.


REVIEWING PROCESS & SUBMISSION GUIDELINES


Submissions of full, blue-sky, and working papers should be original work 
without substantial overlap with pre-published papers. All submissions 
should adhere to IOS formatting guidelines. Papers should be written in 
English and detailed submission instructions can also be found here.



**Important**


HHAI 2025 will follow a double-blind reviewing process. Thus, submissions 
must exclude all information that might disclose the authors’ names or 
affiliations. 


All studies involving human participants should have received 
human-research ethics consent from the relevant institutions and mention 
this in the paper. 


Work should be submitted in PDF format via Easychair following this link: 
https://easychair.org/my/conference?conf=hhai2025


On acceptance, at least one author should attend the conference. A 
significant contribution is expected from all authors. 


PROGRAM CHAIRS


Chiara Boldrini (IIT-CNR, IT)

Luca Pappalardo (ISTI-CNR, IT)

Andrea Passerini (University of Trento, IT)

Shenghui Wang (University of Twente, NL)


CONFERENCE CHAIRS


Michela Milano (University of Bologna, IT)

Dino Pedreschi (University of Pisa, IT)

Stuart Russell (University of California Berkeley, US)

Ilaria Tiddi (Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, NL)


CONTACT INFORMATION


For questions, you can reach the program chairs at: 
program@hhai-conference.org



-- 
You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "EUCog General News" group.
To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to eucog-general-news+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.
To view this discussion visit https://groups.google.com/d/msgid/eucog-general-news/cfa3fa20-ae33-4fc0-b9e0-e3b1f329f177n%40googlegroups.com.

---
(Apologies if you receive multiple copies of this CfP)
  

\---------------------------------------------------------------------
[...]
\---------------------------------------------------------------------
  
[...]

  

\- Human-AI interaction, interpretation and collaboration
\- Adaptive human-AI co-learning and co-creation
\- Learning, reasoning and planning with humans and machines in the loop
\- User modeling and personalisation
\- Integration of learning and reasoning
\- Transparent, explainable, and accountable AI
\- Fair, ethical, responsible, and trustworthy AI
\- Societal awareness of AI
\- Multimodal machine perception of real-world settings
\- Social signal processing
\- Representations learning for Communicative or Collaborative AI
\- Symbolic representations for human-centric AI
\- Human-AI Coevolution
\- Foundation models and humans
\- Human cognition-aware AI
\- Decentralized human-AI systems
\- Reliability and robustness in human-AI systems
\- Applications of hybrid human-AI intelligence
[...]

  

\- Full papers present original, impactful work (12 pages excluding references)
\- Blue sky papers present visionary ideas to stimulate the research community (8 pages excluding references)
\- Working papers present work in progress (8 pages excluding references)
[...]

  

  

\--

headlines: ["Adjust BMM schedule to use recorded Josh Tenenbaum lecture and Zoom Q&A"]
anchors: ["Cogsci 2025", "zoom Q&A", "Lillie Auditorium", "recorded keynote lecture", "BMM afternoon schedule"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Morgan Talbot" <mtalbot@mit.edu>
To: bmm_summer2025@mit.edu
Time: 2025-08-17T12:43:24-04:00
Subject: Change to BMM afternoon schedule: Josh Tenenbaum recorded lecture -> Q&A

Hi everyone,

I'm writing to provide an update to our schedule for this afternoon:

   - Josh Tenenbaum is unfortunately unable to join us in person today due
   to urgent family reasons. In lieu of the planned lecture, Josh has
   suggested that we watch his keynote lecture from the Cogsci 2025
   conference, followed by Q&A over zoom. The theme of the talk in his words
   is "the present moment in which AI and Cog Sci are connecting, and how
   these two fields can best interact in building better theories of human
   cognition"
   - We will set up the video of Josh's Cogsci lecture in Lillie at 1:30pm,
   for anyone who would like to optionally watch it together. You can also
   watch the talk separately if you like, at this link
   <https://us06web.zoom.us/rec/play/_aUf_dKjOQwdu42ox_6BY424QFruGmFjTUTozMpHq9in6SwuLR20M3HFmksezEVUoum9Ve-askp0_2Y.GVjtD_2RJhs9A_W5?eagerLoadZvaPages=sidemenu.billing.plan_management&accessLevel=meeting&canPlayFromShare=true&from=share_recording_detail&continueMode=true&componentName=rec-play&originRequestUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fus06web.zoom.us%2Frec%2Fshare%2FFsflbLDMuWBj9oLumQ6fRGOJTlBFlAvW4alIRocmch9OS6xu8v4bTRbhaxzf7zLx.G0OhjeMXUxjgjRqM>
   (it is a whole-day video, Josh's talk starts at 03:16:55)
   - Josh will join us via Zoom for Q&A from 3pm-4:15pm today (in Lillie
   Auditorium). He says he is happy to take questions about the talk or
   anything else anyone wants to talk about - and he also has some slides that
   relate the content of his talk to the brain, if folks are interested.

Sam Gershman's lecture will proceed afterwards at 4:30pm, as planned.

Best,
Morgan
-- 
*Morgan B. Talbot *(he/him)
MD-PhD Candidate, Harvard/MIT Health Sciences and Technology (HST)
mtalbot@mit.edu

---

full_content:
Message 1
From: "Boscoboinik, J. Anibal" <jboscoboinik@bnl.gov>
To: Boscoboinik, J. Anibal <jboscoboinik@bnl.gov>
Time: 2025-05-07T02:56:06+00:00
Subject: Raíces Este-USA - Mayo 2025

Estimados miembros de Raíces Este-USA (incluye Midwest),

Cosas interesantes o a tener en cuenta este mes:

  1.  Workshop INCOIN - Tecnologías Inteligentes en la Interdisciplinariedad. 8 y 9 de mayo de 2025 - este evento, organizado por el CITEDU (Centro de Innovaciones Tecnológicas para la Docencia Universitaria) y la Secretaría Académica, abordará visiones globales sobre tecnologías inteligentes e interdisciplinariedad, con la participación de actores de la academia, el sector privado y organizaciones civiles, para promover el aprendizaje continuo. QRs abajo para registrarse (gracias Horacio por el dato).
[cid:image001.png@01DBBED8.DC6AC600]

  1.  Próxima reunión:
Fecha: Jueves 22 de mayo
Hora: 6:00 PM (hora del Este)
Enlace Zoom: https://bnl.zoomgov.com/j/1600526082?pwd=t1soPOiiPrhKVzz30mOEnRzxoZLLHB.1
Meeting ID: 160 052 6082
Passcode: 842833

Estamos buscando dos voluntarios que nos cuenten durante la reunión brevemente a que se dedican, así nos vamos conociendo mejor. Los dos primero videos ya están la pagina de la red: https://raices-este.us/#videos (gracias Gabriela de Larrañaga y Guillermo Warley por ser los primeros!). La idea es ir grabándolos en nuestras reuniones trimestrales (también podemos recibir videos que quieran grabar de manera asíncrona).

  2.  Fundación Williams. Fundacion que ofrece subsidios para visitas, organizacion de actividades, etc en Argentina. Tiene cosas interesantes para chusmear: https://fundacionwilliams.org.ar/
  3.  Panel Interredes: Diplomacia Cientítica - "Save the date" 28 de mayo. Las Redes de Alemania y EEUU-Este estamos organizando un panel sobre el rol de las Redes (RCAE) como actores de  diplomacia de la ciencia (extensivo a tecnología e innovación). Este evento esta organizado por Horacio Rotstein de nuestro lado. El panel va a ser el miércoles 28 de mayo a las 13:00 (NYC, EDT), 14:00 (ARG), 19:00 (DE), 20:00 (EEST). Va a quedar grabado para que puedan verlo aquellos que se encuentran en husos horarios para los cuales el horario elegido es inconveniente.

Lxs panelistas van a ser:

Karina Pombo (ex directora de relaciones internacionales del MinCyT)
Paz García Calvo (diplomática, actualmente en la embajada argentina en Egipto)
Aldo Boccaccini (coordinador emerito de red de Alemania)

  1.  Ayudando a Bahía Blanca. Varios miembros de nuestra red, y especialmente Horacio Rotstein, han estado participando activamente en actividades para contribuir a paliar la situación luego de la inundación en Bahía Blanca at través de donaciones. Horacio recibió una carta de agradecimiento de la Fundación de la Universidad Nacional del Sur que se extiende a todos los miembros de nuestra red que han contribuido. Asimismo, hay una colecta actualmente para contribuir a la reconstrucción de la UNS, y este es el link para los que deseen contribuir: https://reconstruir.uns.edu.ar/donaciones

No duden en contactarnos si tienen preguntas, sugerencias, o material que consideren de importancia difundir al resto de los miembros de la red.

Saludos cordiales,
Aníbal Boscoboinik
Coordinador Raíces Este-USA
https://raices-este.us/

-------
PS 1: Horas de Oficina Semanales sobre Inserción en el Sistema Estadounidense para Investigadores Argentinos (Gabriela de Larrañaga, Irina Mindlis y Julieta Bonvin Sallago) - todos los miercoles a las 4 pm ET: meet.google.com/axo-kmfi-rzq
PS 2: No se olviden de unirse al chat en Discord para mantener una comunicación más directa: https://discord.gg/QEYRzfpBrZ
PS 3: LinkedIn de la Red: https://www.linkedin.com/company/raices-este-usa/


J. Anibal Boscoboinik
Center for Functional Nanomaterials
Brookhaven National Laboratory
https://orcid.org/0000-0002-5090-7079


---

  5. **Ayudando a Bahía Blanca**. Varios miembros de nuestra red, y especialmente Horacio Rotstein, han estado participando activamente en actividades para contribuir a paliar la situación luego de la inundación en Bahía Blanca at través de donaciones. Horacio recibió una carta de agradecimiento de la Fundación de la Universidad Nacional del Sur que se extiende a todos los miembros de nuestra red que han contribuido. Asimismo, hay una colecta actualmente para contribuir a la reconstrucción de la UNS, y este es el link para los que deseen contribuir: <https://reconstruir.uns.edu.ar/donaciones>
[...]
Coordinador Raíces Este-USA  
[https://raices-este.us/](https://raices-este.us/)
 
\-------
[...]
PS 2: No se olviden de unirse al chat en Discord para mantener una comunicación más directa: [https://discord.gg/QEYRzfpBrZ](https://discord.gg/QEYRzfpBrZ)  
PS 3: LinkedIn de la Red: [ https://www.linkedin.com/company/raices-este-usa/](https://www.linkedin.com/company/raices-este-usa/)
 
 
J. Anibal Boscoboinik
Center for Functional Nanomaterials
Brookhaven National Laboratory

headlines: ["Dianna asks me to review student's NE240 project design issues"]
anchors: ["assignment 1 requirements", "simulate human vision", "project design problems", "level of specificity", "evaluation of background"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Hidalgo, Dianna" <diannahidalgo@g.harvard.edu>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-02-11T16:41:28-05:00
Subject: Fwd: Problem facing for the project design

Do you mind checking this out?
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Enhui/Mike Li <enhuimike_li@college.harvard.edu>
Date: Sun, Feb 9, 2025 at 11:25 AM
Subject: Re: Problem facing for the project design
To: <gabriel.kreiman@tch.harvard.edu>, <diannahidalgo@g.harvard.edu>, <
anitej_thamma@g.harvard.edu>




On Sun, Feb 9, 2025 at 11:24 AM Enhui/Mike Li <
enhuimike_li@college.harvard.edu> wrote:

> Dear Dr. Kreiman, Dr. Hidalgo, Teacher Thamma,
>
> I hope this letter finds you well!
>
> I am currently facing some problems in designing the project. I found that
> the projects I wanted to accomplish could be achieved by completing two
> goals. But the design of the second goal (including database, model design)
> may need to change based on the results of the first goal and the process
> of my own learning. I can't detail the second design right now. And I want
> CNN to simulate human vision in a variety of ways, but so far I've only
> come up with one that's holistic processing.
>
>
> I would like to implore for your help in showing me:
>
> 1. How to simulate human vision from other perspectives such as analyzing
> the environmental impact.
>
> 2: I wonder if my sloppy design of my second goal, which will almost
> certainly change in the future, will meet the requirements of Assignment 1.
>
> 3. I also hope to get your evaluation, to see if I, as a student learning
> ML with programming experience and shallow AI experience, can meet my level
> of project design, and on the basis of certain challenges, I can complete
> this task with enough hard work.
>
> 4. Please also give me some insight into the level of specificity in the
> design of this task.
>
> I highly appreciate your help!
>
>
> In the following two attachments, "project design" is the homework I want
> to submit, and it is a very brief introduction of my project design.
> "specific" is my introduction to my project and the small experiments that
> have been designed within it.
>
> As a sophomore majoring in CS, deeply influenced by my parents, I have
> been passionate about biology since junior high school. I hope that this
> semester I can fully achieve my goals from this course and my project, have
> some challenges to myself, and gain some knowledge and understanding of the
> intersection of computer and neurology. Thank you very much for your help!
> Sorry to bother you on Sunday morning!
>
> Best regards,
> Enhui Li
>
>

---
Do you mind checking this out?  

\---------- Forwarded message ---------  
From: **Enhui/Mike Li** <[enhuimike_li@college.harvard.edu](mailto:enhuimike_li@college.harvard.edu)>

Message 1
From: Spandan Madan <spandan.madan@gmail.com>
To: Ansh Shah <anshshah3009@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-04-15T14:13:31-04:00
Subject: Benchmarking experiment

Hi Ansh,

Got excited, and did a bunch of things. I am attaching all the files you
will need.

The file benchmarking.ipynb will set you up to access all the combined
information i.e. what we called All of D in our call today. You can ignore
combining_raw_data.ipynb, I already combined all D together for your
convenience.

processed_data_K contains what we have.

Ideally, what we would want to do:

Go over all the questions in the
file gabriel_qa_extended_w_meetings_and_emails.csv and generate an answer
for it from OpenAI/Gemini/ etc.

For OpenAI I think you will have to do some chunking etc as the context is
too large for it.

The results will ultimately be filled out here:

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Mhzl1YXDSSPT-ZIt_Y9rvb38o2i0qJWjlhtrfogSjV8/edit?usp=sharing


I am attaching PDF of the call notes too. Let's meet this
Thursday/Friday---can you please pick a time on my calendly? Of course,
feel free to book an earlier time if something is unclear.

Exciting stuff! Talk to you soon!

---

full_content:
Message 1
From: "The Lowy Int'l School @ Tel Aviv University" <study@tau.ac.il>
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-03-17T13:59:33+00:00
Subject: March 17, 2025: Updates from TAU's Global Home

**Updates from TAU's global home. Monday, March 17, 2025.**

**For Faculty**

* 

**Lowy Visiting Lecturers:** Want to join TAU for 2 to 4 weeks and teach a concentrated course? Simply let a TAU colleague know and they can nominate you. 

**(Are you a TAU faculty member? Then consider nominating an international colleague of yours.)** Nominations for candidates are due on May 29, 2025. Candidates are entitled to 7,000 to 8,500 USD to cover expenses. Learn more here (see page 2 for English) https://international.tau.ac.il/sites/english.register.tau.ac.il/files/media_server/TAU%20international/joint%20collaboration/%D7%94%D7%96%D7%9E%D7%A0%D7%AA%20%D7%9E%D7%A8%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%9D%20%D7%90%D7%95%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%99%D7%9D%20%D7%9E%D7%97%D7%95%D7%9C%20-%20%D7%A9%D7%A0%D7%AA%20%D7%94%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9E%D7%95%D7%93%D7%99%D7%9D%20%D7%AA%D7%A9%D7%A4%D7%95.pdf.

* 

**Collaborative International Courses:** We are currently accepting applications for collaborative international course grants https://international.tau.ac.il/sites/english.register.tau.ac.il/files/media_server/TAU%20international/Partnerships%20and%20Exchange/COILs%202025-6%20ENG_.pdf (3,000 USD per grant). Courses can cover any academic topic. Eligible joint courses must be taught by a TAU instructor in collaboration with a colleague(s) from at least one other university. Deadline for proposals: May 29, 2025.

**For Postdocs**

* 

**TAU Scholarships:** TAU is offering 16 postdoctoral fellowships for the 2025-26 academic year. Majority of scholarships open to all disciplines. Learn more and apply by March 23, 2025 https://acad-sec.tau.ac.il/phd/scholarship-2025-english.

* 

**Zuckerman Scholarships:** The Zuckerman Postdoctoral Scholarships Program funds STEM research by American and Canadian postdocs at TAU for up to two years (63,000 USD per year). Apply by March 31, 2025 https://zuckermanstem.org/ourprograms/postdoc-program/.

**For Students**

* 

**Short-Term Fellowships for Research Students**: We're offering 15,000 to 30,000 NIS (approximately 4,000 to 8,000 USD) to international master's or doctoral students interested in conducting research at TAU for 3 to 6 months. Open to students in the sciences and environmental studies. Learn more and apply by April 24, 2025 https://international.tau.ac.il/sites/english.register.tau.ac.il/files/media_server/TAU%20international/Partnerships%20and%20Exchange/Research%20Fellowships%20%282%29.pdf.

* 

**Short-Term Fellowships for PhD Students:** The Azrieli Visiting PhD Fellowship https://azrielifoundation.org/fellows/visiting-phd-fellowship/#overview gives PhD candidates the opportunity to conduct short-term research at TAU. The fellowship is open to all academic disciplines, and candidates receive 12,000 NIS (approximately 3,200 USD) per month. Apply by April 2, 2025.

**CONTACT US**

**The Lowy International School**

**Tel Aviv University**

Ramat Aviv

Israel, 6997801

Tel: +972-73-3804534

study@tauex.tau.ac.il mailto:study@tauex.tau.ac.il

View our offices in your country https://international.tau.ac.il/international_center

https://www.facebook.com/TAU.International/ 

https://x.com/tauintl 

https://www.linkedin.com/company/lowy-international-school/mycompany/ 

https://www.youtube.com/@TAUInternational1

**For Faculty**  
|   
---  
|   
---  
  * **Lowy Visiting Lecturers:** Want to join TAU for 2 to 4 weeks and teach a concentrated course? Simply let a TAU colleague know and they can nominate you. _(Are you a TAU faculty member? Then consider nominating an international colleague of yours.)_ Nominations for candidates are due on May 29, 2025. Candidates are entitled to 7,000 to 8,500 USD to cover expenses. [Learn more here (see page 2 for English)](https://telavivuniversityinternational1606128003.acemlna.com/lt.php?x=3DZy~GDDIIGi6s.uzQ~IgxVw2aEivQP3lhswXKXLUFGd75z5yky.zuJu3Y2kj_A~juVAXXTKJU).
  * **Collaborative International Courses:** We are currently accepting applications for [collaborative international course grants](https://telavivuniversityinternational1606128003.acemlna.com/lt.php?x=3DZy~GDDIIGi6s.uzQ~IgxVw2aEivQP3lhswXKXLUFGd75z5yky.zuJu3Y2kj_A~juVAXXTKJk) (3,000 USD per grant). Courses can cover any academic topic. Eligible joint courses must be taught by a TAU instructor in collaboration with a colleague(s) from at least one other university. Deadline for proposals: May 29, 2025.

  
|   
---  
**For Postdocs**  
|   
---  
  * **TAU Scholarships:** TAU is offering 16 postdoctoral fellowships for the 2025-26 academic year. Majority of scholarships open to all disciplines. [Learn more and apply by March 23, 2025](https://telavivuniversityinternational1606128003.acemlna.com/lt.php?x=3DZy~GDDIIGi6s.uzQ~IgxVw2aEivQP3lhswXKXLUFGd75z5yky.zuJu3Y2kj_A~juVAXXTKJ0).
  * **Zuckerman Scholarships:** The Zuckerman Postdoctoral Scholarships Program funds STEM research by American and Canadian postdocs at TAU for up to two years (63,000 USD per year). [Apply by March 31, 2025](https://telavivuniversityinternational1606128003.acemlna.com/lt.php?x=3DZy~GDDIIGi6s.uzQ~IgxVw2aEivQP3lhswXKXLUFGd75z5yky.zuJu3Y2kj_A~juVAXXTKJC).

  
|   
---  
**For Students**  
|   
---  
  * **Short-Term Fellowships for Research Students** : We're offering 15,000 to 30,000 NIS (approximately 4,000 to 8,000 USD) to international master's or doctoral students interested in conducting research at TAU for 3 to 6 months. Open to students in the sciences and environmental studies. [Learn more and apply by April 24, 2025](https://telavivuniversityinternational1606128003.acemlna.com/lt.php?x=3DZy~GDDIIGi6s.uzQ~IgxVw2aEivQP3lhswXKXLUFGd75z5yky.zuJu3Y2kj_A~juVAXXTKKU).
  * **Short-Term Fellowships for PhD Students:** The [Azrieli Visiting PhD Fellowship](https://telavivuniversityinternational1606128003.acemlna.com/lt.php?x=3DZy~GDDIIGi6s.uzQ~IgxVw2aEivQP3lhswXKXLUFGd75z5yky.zuJu3Y2kj_A~juVAXXTKKk) gives PhD candidates the opportunity to conduct short-term research at TAU. The fellowship is open to all academic disciplines, and candidates receive 12,000 NIS (approximately 3,200 USD) per month. Apply by April 2, 2025.

headlines: ["Confirmation of participation in UCSF BrainMind Science Collective"]
anchors: ["accommodations provided", "transit expenses", "pre events", "dinner with experts", "opening reception"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Diana Saville <diana@brainmind.org>
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-02-05T14:46:24+00:00
Subject: Confirmation - UCSF BrainMind Science Collective

Dear Gabriel,

We are thrilled to confirm your participation in the *UCSF BrainMind
Science Collective, March 21-23, 2025*. Please look out for your calendar
invitations for the events. Details below:

*Friday, March 21st, 2025*

   - *Pre Events (Day 1)*
      - 10:00 AM Special Topic Breakouts
      - 12:00 PM Lunch Session
      - 2:00 PM Special Topic Breakouts
   - *Opening Reception (Day 1)*
      - 6:00pm - 9:00pm

*Saturday, March 22nd, 2025*

   - *BrainMind Science Collective (Day 2)*
      - UCSF, Mission Bay Conference Center (1675 Owens Street San
      Francisco, CA 94143)
      - 8:00am - 6:00pm
   - *A Feast of Ideas: Dinner with BrainMind Experts*
      - UCSF, Mission Bay Conference Center – same address
      - 6:00pm - 9:00pm


*Sunday, March 23rd, 2025*

   - *BrainMind Science Collective (Day 3)*
      - UCSF, Mission Bay Conference Center – same address
      - 8:00am - 6:00pm

Accommodations will be provided to maximize community building during the
gathering; however, if you prefer to stay somewhere specific, you are
welcome to book alternative lodging at your own expense. As a reminder,
participants are expected to arrange and cover their own transit expenses.
Limited travel grants are available for early-career scientists and those
facing special circumstances—if you need to apply, send me a note.

This gathering is invitation-only. However, we warmly welcome referrals for
participation, guided by your personal discernment of character,
authenticity, and talent. If you know exceptional individuals who would be
a great fit, please email us with your recommendations.

We are happy to help with any questions you have in the meantime - drop us
a line!


Warmly,

Diana, Michael, and the BrainMind team

---
Diana, Michael, and the BrainMind team  

![](https://diana_brainmind_org-dot-mm-event.appspot.com/em_EEgkmUgl6hbptW0WM5BU/meteor.gif)

Message 1
From: "Boscoboinik, J. Anibal" <jboscoboinik@bnl.gov>
To: Boscoboinik, J. Anibal <jboscoboinik@bnl.gov>
Time: 2025-06-28T19:58:27+00:00
Subject: Actualizaciones RAICES Este USA – Junio 2025

Estimados miembros de Raíces Este-USA (incluye Midwest),

Esperos que se encuentren bien. Le comparto las novedades del mes de junio:

________________________________

[📢]Ley de Financiamiento Universitario

El Consejo Interuniversitario Nacional (CIN), la Federación Universitaria Argentina (FUA) y el Frente Sindical de Universidades Nacionales invitan a la comunidad universitaria y general a adherir de manera personal al proyecto de Ley de Financiamiento de la Educación Superior que presentaron en la Comisión de Educación del Honorable Cámara de Diputados de la Nación el 28 de mayo.
[✍️] Adhesiones: Formulario<https://kollacin.siu.edu.ar/kollacin/aplicacion.php?ai=kolla||40000174&h=103&f=107>

________________________________


 Situación del financiamiento científico en Argentina – Material compilado por RAICES Alemania

  1.  [📄]  Nota del CIN: “La universidad pública y la ciencia, en crisis profunda”<https://www.cin.edu.ar/la-universidad-publica-y-la-ciencia-en-crisis-profunda/>

  2.  [🎥]  Presentaciones de científicos ante el Senado (04/06/25):
     *   Ariel Pereda<https://youtu.be/qxk3j1F2eQk?si=nw4Ynjvp9Z5CkhSk>
     *   Mario Pecheny<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uaShlRduRK4>
     *   Miguel Schiavini<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mm-X8yZsF3c>
     *   Jorge Geffner<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z6NznvWxtBI>
     *   Diego Hurtado<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gOQZVShNgc0>
     *   Valeria Levy<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QgTUArdes-o>
  3.  [📜]  Declaración de la Academia Nacional de Ciencias (6/6/25):
 Ver documento<https://www.anc-argentina.org.ar/2025/06/06/15222/>

________________________________

[📚] Nueva Cohorte 2025–2026 de la Diplomatura en Diplomacia Científica – FCNyM, UNLP
Está abierta la inscripción para la próxima cohorte de la Diplomatura de Posgrado en Diplomacia Científica coordinada por Karina Pombo y Sandra Torrusio.
[📅] Inicio: 22 de agosto de 2025
[💻] Modalidad: A distancia
[🧾] Compuesta por 5 cursos independientes (pueden cursarse por separado)

Cronograma:

  *   Curso 1 – Introducción, conceptos y actores (22/8 al 12/9/25)
  *   Curso 2 – Estrategias avanzadas y aplicaciones (24/10 al 14/11/25)
  *   Curso 3 – Comunicación internacional (marzo/abril 2026)
  *   Curso 4 – Diplomacia de la innovación (mayo 2026)
  *   Curso 5 – Bioeconomía y desarrollo regional (junio 2026)

[📩] Más información: programa.diplomacia@gsuite.fcnym.unlp.edu.ar<mailto:programa.diplomacia@gsuite.fcnym.unlp.edu.ar>

________________________________

 Conocé a los miembros de nuestra red
[👉] Segui a Raices Este USA en LinkedIn y descubrí lo que hacen los científicos argentinos de nuestra red: LinkedIn RAICES Este USA<https://www.linkedin.com/company/raices-este-usa/> (gracias Andrea Capurro!)[🎙️] Video del miembro Román Baravalle. Román nos cuenta a que se dedica, y contesta algunas preguntas durante la ultima reunión de la red (estamos buscando voluntarios para la próxima reunión!): https://youtu.be/XKHcs2iDvrM

________________________________

[🧪] Solidaridad con Bahía Blanca – Reconstrucción de laboratorios
El Departamento de Física de la Universidad Nacional del Sur sufrió daños devastadores tras las inundaciones del 7 de marzo. Casi todo el equipamiento fue destruido. Se puede colaborar con donaciones:

[💸] https://reconstruir.uns.edu.ar/donaciones
 Contacto: Marcelo Costabel, marcelo.costabel@uns.edu.ar<mailto:marcelo.costabel@uns.edu.ar>

La carta completa al respecto que nos enviaron de la Asociación Física Argentina vá adjunta este mensaje.

________________________________

No duden en contactarnos si tienen preguntas, sugerencias, o material que consideren de importancia difundir al resto de los miembros de la red.
Saludos cordiales,
Aníbal Boscoboinik
Coordinador Raíces Este-USA
https://raices-este.us/

-------
PS 1: Horas de Oficina Semanales sobre Inserción en el Sistema Estadounidense para Investigadores Argentinos (Gabriela de Larrañaga, Irina Mindlis y Julieta Bonvin Sallago) – los miercoles a las 4 pm ET: meet.google.com/axo-kmfi-rzq
PS 2: No se olviden de unirse al chat en Discord para mantener una comunicación más directa: https://discord.gg/QEYRzfpBrZ
PS 3: LinkedIn de la Red: https://www.linkedin.com/company/raices-este-usa/


J. Anibal Boscoboinik
Center for Functional Nanomaterials
Brookhaven National Laboratory
https://orcid.org/0000-0002-5090-7079


---

headlines: ["Mengmi Zhang proposes research collaboration on dog vocalization recordings"]
anchors: ["on-site visit", "dog vocalizations", "naturalistic settings", "research grant", "visual and audio recordings"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Zhang Mengmi (Asst Prof)" <mengmi.zhang@ntu.edu.sg>
To: happy_dogtraining@yahoo.com.sg <happy_dogtraining@yahoo.com.sg>
Time: 2025-09-11T06:06:29+00:00
Subject: Research Collaboration on Dog Vocalization Study

Dear Dog Training Team,
My name is Mengmi Zhang, Assistant Professor in College of Computing and Data Science at NTU. Our team plans to study dog vocalizations in naturalistic settings using Artificial Intelligence (AI), collecting visual and audio recordings to better understand how dogs communicate.
We are planning to apply for a research grant next year (e.g., AI for Science / CRP) to support this work and are very interested in a research collaboration with you. We would love to arrange a short meeting and on-site visit to discuss whether it’s possible to collect recordings at your facility in a non-intrusive, welfare-friendly way.
We would acknowledge your support in publications and share research insights that may benefit your work with dogs.
Please let us know if you are open to research collaborations. Thank you for your time, and we look forward to your reply.
Best,

Mengmi
Nanyang assistant professor and PI of Deep NeuroCognition Lab
College of Computing and Data Science
Nanyang Technological University
Lab website: https://a0091624.wixsite.com/deepneurocognition-1
________________________________

CONFIDENTIALITY: This email is intended solely for the person(s) named and may be confidential and/or privileged. If you are not the intended recipient, please delete it, notify us and do not copy, use, or disclose its contents.
Towards a sustainable earth: Print only when necessary. Thank you.

---

headlines: ["Welcome and onboarding requests for AI Lab for Startups program"]
anchors: ["Innovation Committee presentations", "Core Mentor meetings", "quarterly milestones", "introductory Zoom call", "pitch deck and bios"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Kleiman, Debi" <dkleiman@hbs.edu>
To: 
  - Madan, Spandan <spandan_madan@seas.harvard.edu>
  - Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-01-28T00:55:54+00:00
Subject: Welcome to the AI Lab for Startups!

Gabriel and Spandan,
Welcome to the program! We're thrilled to have you join us and look forward to supporting your venture through our resources, mentorship, and community of fellow academic founders.

Let me outline our key program components:

Programming, Mentors & Updates
- We host monthly/bi-monthly Zoom sessions covering essential entrepreneurial topics with expert speakers (highly recommended, though not mandatory)
- Each quarter, you'll set and work toward 3 specific milestones. Quarterly presentations to our Innovation Committee, where you'll share progress on your milestones, are required to maintain your spot in the program.
- Within the next week, I'll connect you with your Core Mentor, who will meet with you at least twice monthly (frequency can be adjusted based on your needs).


Next Steps
1. Please send me:
   - Your latest executive summary or pitch deck
   - A brief pitch (2-3 sentences)
   - Short bios for team members

2. I'll begin scheduling our regular sessions. Could you confirm if both team members will be participating fully? Also, please let me know if I may share your contact information with our mentors.

3. I'd love to schedule a Zoom call to walk you through all our available resources and how to access them. We can also dive into where you think you need the most help right now so that I can line up the most relevant mentors. You can book a time that works best for you through my Calendly link: https://calendly.com/meetwithdebikleiman/intromtg

Looking forward to supporting your entrepreneurial journey!
Best,
Debi


[Image]Debi Kleiman | The AI Lab for Startups | Digital Data Design Institute at Harvard<http://d3.harvard.edu/>  | HARVARD BUSINESS SCHOOL


---

------------------------------
*From:* Director, Student Affairs <D-SAO@ntu.edu.sg>
*Sent:* Monday, October 6, 2025 10:07 AM
*Subject:* Human! Join Us at TEDxNTU 2025 for Inspiring Conversations


[image: A close up of a purple background AI-generated content may be
incorrect.]

Dear NTU Community

On behalf of *NTU World of Wisdom*, the knowledge-outreach platform of the
NTU Graduate Students’ Association, I am delighted to invite you to the
*15th TEDxNTU.*

This year’s theme, *RE: Human*, explores what it means to be human in an
age of rapid technological change. Through talks that reflect how people
adapt, resist, and reinvent themselves amid evolving digital landscapes,
TEDxNTU 2025 aims to spark conversations on empathy, creativity, and
solidarity – encouraging us to reconnect with our shared humanity while
embracing the future. More about our team and speakers can be found
<https://www.tedxntu.sg/event/re-human>*HERE*
<https://www.tedxntu.sg/event/re-human>.



*Event Details*



*Date*

: 18 October 2025 (Saturday)

*Time*

: 2.00 PM – 6.00 PM

  followed by refreshment and engagement with speakers

  from 6.00 PM – 7.00 PM

*Venue*

: Nanyang Auditorium

*Dress Code*

: Smart Casual



Don’t miss this opportunity to be part of an inspiring afternoon. Each
attendee will receive a special goodie (while stocks last).



Register *HERE*
<https://www.eventbrite.sg/e/tedxntu-2025-rehuman-tickets-1633299666269?aff=oddtdtcreator>
to
secure your seat.



[image: A poster of a group of people AI-generated content may be
incorrect.] <https://www.tedxntu.sg/event/re-human>





Best wishes

headlines: ["Martin provides EPFL PhD admissions and hiring information to Shreyas"]
topics: ["EPFL PhD and RA opportunities for Shreyas"]
anchors: ["grant outcomes", "summer programs", "central programs", "EDIC", "EDNE"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Martin Schrimpf <martin.schrimpf@epfl.ch>
To: Shreyas K <f20200714@goa.bits-pilani.ac.in>
Time: 2025-05-26T08:09:07+00:00
Subject: RE: Introduction

Hi Shreyas, and thank you Gabriel for the introduction,

Nice to meet you! And sorry for missing the initial emails, I’m only checking my MIT inbox sporadically.

PhD admissions at EPFL are handled via central programs. Specifically, I’m hiring from the EDIC and EDNE programs, please see here for more information: https://www.epfl.ch/labs/schrimpflab/#prospective.
I’m currently waiting for the outcome of some grants, which will inform whether I can hire this year. If you’d like to come visit, the EPFL summer programs might be interesting (see link above).

Best,
Martin

From: Shreyas K <f20200714@goa.bits-pilani.ac.in>
Sent: Monday, May 26, 2025 9:30 AM
To: Martin Schrimpf <martin.schrimpf@epfl.ch>
Subject: Re: Introduction

Hi Martin,

Just checking in—an update would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

Regards,
Shreyas

On Thu, May 22, 2025 at 9:28 PM Shreyas K <f20200714@goa.bits-pilani.ac.in<mailto:f20200714@goa.bits-pilani.ac.in>> wrote:

Hi Martin,

This is Shreyas, as Gabriel mentioned. I found your work, "The Neural Architecture of Language: Integrative Modeling Converges on Predictive Processing," to be closely related to my current research under Pranav and Gabriel, which will soon be submitted for publication.

I’m currently pursuing my master’s thesis under Gabriel. In my thesis, I evaluated representations of language in LLMs and in the human brain using invasive neurophysiology, working alongside Pranav, Spandan, and Gabriel. This work has resulted in two manuscripts that are currently under submission.

I’m very interested in joining your lab as a PhD student or as an RA. I’ve attached my CV for your reference and would greatly appreciate it if you could let me know about any available opportunities. Thank you!

Warm regards,
Shreyas

PhD admissions at EPFL are handled via central programs. Specifically, I’m hiring from the EDIC and EDNE programs, please see here for more information: <https://www.epfl.ch/labs/schrimpflab/#prospective>.
[...]

headlines: ["Lecture at Brains, Minds, and Machines summer course confirmed"]
topics: ["Brains, Minds, and Machines summer course lecture"]
anchors: ["Lillie auditorium", "running race road closures", "lecture schedule", "parking information"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Morgan Talbot" <mtalbot@mit.edu>
To: gershman@fas.harvard.edu
Time: 2025-08-15T17:21:50-04:00
Subject: Your lecture this Sunday 4:30pm at Brains, Minds, & Machines in Woods Hole

Dear Professor Gershman,

I am writing to confirm the details regarding your lecture at the Brains,
Minds, and Machines summer course -  I am one of the TAs. The lecture is
scheduled for this Sunday, *August 17th, from 4:30pm to 5:45pm, in Lillie
auditorium* (7 Mbl St, Woods Hole, MA 02543). I'll be there if you happen
to need anything - please feel free to let me know.

*Important* *detail (roads/parking): *there is a large running race that
starts in Woods Hole on Sunday morning, which will close roads into Woods
Hole/in the surrounding area - we've been told all of this should be back
to normal by around 10am. If driving, you can park behind the Lillie
building or anywhere on campus - there is no need for a permit on the
weekend. If you have any questions or concerns, please let us know.

Thank you for your willingness to make the trip - we are very much looking
forward to hearing your talk!

Best wishes,
Morgan Talbot
-- 
*Morgan B. Talbot *(he/him)
MD-PhD Candidate, Harvard/MIT Health Sciences and Technology (HST)
mtalbot@mit.edu

---

Message 1
From: Jenni Goodman <jenni@underscore.vc>
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-05-19T07:07:20-07:00
Subject: You're Invited: Avoid AI Pitfalls – Join Undescore VC on 6/18 (In Person or Virtual)

Hi Gabriel,


Building with AI holds incredible potential—but also plenty of pitfalls.
That’s why Underscore VC and WilmerHale are hosting a tactical session
designed specifically for AI founders.



Join us on June 18th from 2-3pm ET to explore the most common mistakes made
when building and implementing AI solutions—and how to avoid them.


You’ll learn practical strategies to help you:

   -

   Save time and resources
   -

   Navigate legal and regulatory challenges
   -

   Steer clear of technical and operational missteps as you scale



Attend in person in Boston or join virtually via Zoom. Space is limited—RSVP
here
<https://event.underscore.vc/underscore-vc/rsvp/invite?e=ai-potholes-for-founders-to-avoid&inviteId=8WxQXmnCQ9g8rzAkg9Bu4W>.

headlines: ["I ask Spandan for guidance on employer documents and offer letter", "Law firm requests H-1B petition questionnaire and checklist completion"]
topics: ["H-1B Specialty Occupation Workers Change of Status petition for Spandan Madan"]
people: ["Spandan Madan <spandan.madan@gmail.com>", "Marlene Mugge - Goldman & Partners Immigration Law LLP \"(using inszoom.net)\" <notifications@inszoom.net>", "I", "Spandan Madan"]
anchors: ["checklist", "employment offer letter", "other points", "document upload", "access code", "online questionnaire", "questionnaire email forward", "INSZoom website printout", "Send Confirmation"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Marlene Mugge - Goldman & Partners Immigration Law LLP "(using inszoom.net)"
	<notifications@inszoom.net>
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-04-04T00:54:46+00:00
Subject: Employer Questionnaire and Checklist: Memorious Inc./ Spandan Madan

Dear Gabriel,   
  
We have started working on the petition for H-1B Specialty Occupation Workers Change of Status on behalf of Spandan Madan.  Below please find instructions for how to access an online questionnaire and checklist that includes all the information and evidence we need from Memorious Inc. to prepare the petition.   
  

You can upload all the required documents directly to our electronic system by clicking on "_Upload New Doc_ " that can be found on the right side of each item in the checklist.
 
Please then complete the online questionnaire and click "_Send Confirmation_ " once you are completely finished with everything, both the questionnaire and checklist.  Please also understand once you click _Send Confirmation_ , you will no longer be able to access the link anymore, therefore please only submit once done with everything.  
  
Thank you very much, and if you have any questions please feel free to email.
 
 
 
 
 
  

  

  
Click below to access important information required to continue processing your case. Your access code is **AGGCY5925431751719488**  
[Access Item(s)](https://global.inszoom.com/Corpdocs/dcqtext.aspx?QOrgId=OPlojg&q=Q24qnl4s8B1UK%2bgwlbiZEVjJyt6tMO1t8t9hoDzpm%2bY%3d&QQstInd=AdvStKt "Click here to open Enclosed Items")  
---  
  
  
You may also copy and paste this link to a browser: [https://global.inszoom.com/Corpdocs/dcqtext.aspx?QOrgId=OPlojg&q;=Q24qnl4s8B1UK%2bgwlbiZEVjJyt6tMO1t8t9hoDzpm%2bY%3d&QQstInd;=AdvStKt](https://global.inszoom.com/Corpdocs/dcqtext.aspx?QOrgId=OPlojg&q=Q24qnl4s8B1UK%2bgwlbiZEVjJyt6tMO1t8t9hoDzpm%2bY%3d&QQstInd=AdvStKt)  
  
Access will expire on **Friday, April 3, 2026.**  
  

  
Do not directly reply to this email. To reply, [**Click here**](https://global.inszoom.com/corpdocs/docs_email_reply_access_code_auth.aspx?QBnfId=BGGCY12649&QMsgId=Q24qnl4s8B1UK+gwlbiZEVjJyt6tMO1t8t9hoDzpm+Y=&QInd=casereply&QCaseID=KBGGCY12649-2&q=Q24qnl4s8B1UK+gwlbiZEVjJyt6tMO1t8t9hoDzpm+Y=&QOrgId=OPlojg "Click here to send reply for this email") and input access code: **AGGCY5925431751719488**  
  
  

Thank You
Marlene Mugge 
Email: Marlene@gpimmigration.com 
 
ABOUT THIS E-MAIL: The content of this email is intended only for the person or entity to which it is addressed. It may contain confidential and/or privileged material. Any review, retransmission, dissemination, taking of any action in reliance upon this information or other use of this by persons or entities other than the intended recipient is prohibited. If you are not the intended recipient, please inform the sender and delete this material from your computer.

From: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>

headlines: ["Identify and respond to error in submitted Mooney cover letter"]

full_content:
Message 1
From: Marcelo Armendariz <marcelo.armenz@gmail.com>
To: 
  - Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
  - Gabriel Kreiman <Gabriel.Kreiman@childrens.harvard.edu>
Time: 2025-07-22T00:13:02-04:00
Subject: ERROR in Mooney Cover Letter

Hi Gabriel,
There is an error in the submitted cover letter, title is wrong, and it says "research article in Nature.”, not Science.
Can this be corrected?
---


Message 2
From: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
To: Marcelo Armendariz <marcelo.armenz@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-07-22T08:00:26-04:00
Subject: Re: ERROR in Mooney Cover Letter

Mmm... Seems like I messed up with the cover letter. I am sorry about that.
I checked and I cannot change it now. We could email the editors but I
think that this is worth at this point.
If they find anything that needs to be changed for the submission
(sometimes this happens when the administrative people check the paper),
then we can change it. It is not good but it is not the end of the world.
Editors receive this kind of cover letter errors all the time. Mea culpa.

Regardless, we should think about where to send to next in case it is
editorially rejected, which is always a strong possibility with these
journals.


On Tue, Jul 22, 2025 at 12:13 AM Marcelo Armendariz <
marcelo.armenz@gmail.com> wrote:

> Hi Gabriel,
[...]
> Can this be corrected?
>


-- 
Gabriel Kreiman

http://klab.tch.harvard.edu

full_content:
Message 1
From: Sharad Ramanathan <sharad@cgr.harvard.edu>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-04-23T14:18:00-04:00
Subject: chenguang

Dear Gabriel
out of curiosity, googled Chenguang and found a page:
https://www.sainsburywellcome.org/web/people/chenguang-li
I guess she did join the one lab she interviewed with. Ann Duan called me
up as a reference a before Chenguang graduated, and Chenguang had told me
that she was not really interested.

Since we talked about her, I thought I should send you some googling
results! Not sure Chenguang will keep in touch since she just disappeared
after her thesis exam and did not talk to me after.

Hope you are holding up ok.

I've been asking friends at the hospitals for a PI appointment for me so i
can apply for grants without going through Harvard proper, but it seems
difficult.
Hopefully the lawsuit pans out, but in the long run, things look bleaker
than they did a year ago.

warm regards and hope to run into you soon
Sharad

---

Subject: Re: chenguang

I am very sorry for the late reply. I have been traveling.

I did not know about Chenguang's whereabouts. I was a bit surprised by her
lack of contact after her thesis. Oh well. I hope that she is doing well
and that she is excited about her postdoctoral work.

The hospitals are, as of now, slightly less affected than Harvard with the
current administration. That said, I am trying to get out of the hospitals
asap, I do not think that this is a very good environment for basic
science. But I do understand how crazy and uncertain everything is with
grants right now. I do hope that things will evolve for the better and that
Trump will find other things to entertain himself.

On a personal note, my children are now out of the house and I have been
thinking about what I want to do next. I am starting a new company focused
on memory and helping people with memory deficits, together with a student
who just graduated. We are just at the beginning stages but I am quite
excited about it.

headlines: ["Hector shares four top candidates for BMM 2025"]
people: ["Roman Beliy", "Kathy Garcia", "Robert (Max) Dabagia", "Hector Luis Penagos-Vargas <penagos@mit.edu>", "Yan Zhuang", "I"]
anchors: ["BMM 2025", "top candidates", "research descriptions", "applicants reviewed"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Hector Luis Penagos-Vargas <penagos@mit.edu>
To: klabcoordinator@gmail.com <klabcoordinator@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-04-13T22:29:18+00:00
Subject: Top candidates for BMM 2025

Hi Gabriel,

Below are the four top candidates from the pool of applicants I reviewed.

See you at MBL!

Hector

Kathy Garcia (Module 1). PhD student in Leyla Isik’s group at Hopkins. Kathy’s research centers on understanding how the brain extracts information from sequences of dynamical visual input and how to implement her findings in computer vision algorithms. Kathy has several publications and has experience in both academic research and industry applications as a data scientist. She is a first-generation indigenous Guatemalan to graduate college, while also providing financial support for her family.
Robert (Max) Dabagia (Module 2). PhD student in Santosh Vempala’s group at Georgia Tech planning to start a postdoc with Christos Papadimitriou later this year. Max has been responsible for the latest developments in the mathematical model of the brain, NEMO, enabling it to learn algorithms or exhibit attention and solve analogy tasks.
Roman Beliy (Module 3). PhD student in Math and Computer Science at the Weizmann Institute. As a graduate student, Roman pioneered the development of contemporary analysis techniques using machine learning to decode images from fMRI signals. His NeurIPs papers are highly cited. Per his PhD advisor, Roman is the driving force of the most exciting developments in the lab contributing novel ideas and implementing them into code. He has done a lot of this work despite dealing with challenging personal circumstances including the death of his mother.
Yan Zhuang (Modules 3-4). Yan is finishing a masters degree with Tianmin Shu at Hopkins and will start his PhD with Yen-Ling Kuo at UVA in Computer Science in the Fall. During his masters program, Yan has worked as a developer of a state-of-the-art outdoor world simulator for multi-agent interactions. He has been the leader of this effort coordinating the work between labs at Hopkins and UCSD. At UVA, Yan will work on Markov Decision Processes in robotic settings to enable robot-human interactions. The work he did in his masters demonstrates he works well in a fast-paced environments.


---

headlines: ["I explain concerns about possible conflict of interest with Alex Bowers", "I outline possible next steps and constraints for resubmitting the proposal", "I respond about impact of Alex Bowers\u2019s review and other negative critiques", "John considers meeting with PO Cheri Wiggs about reviewer conduct", "John consults PO and SRO about potential conflicts in grant application review", "John uses ChatGPT to hypothesize likely reviewers based on critique writing styles"]
people: ["Cheri", "PO", "Alexandra Rae Bowers, PhD", "SRO", "Sonia Chernova, PhD", "Pezaris, John <Pezaris.John@mgh.harvard.edu>", "Ava K. Bittner, OD, PhD", "Gianfranco Doretto, PhD", "Alex Bowers", "I", "Cheri Wiggs"]
anchors: ["conflicts were checked", "critique 4", "roster", "potential conflicts", "unpublished random conference abstract", "negative reviews", "reviewers were out of line", "easy to address and change", "critique 3", "critique 1", "specific reviewers", "meeting with PO", "average scores", "conflict of interest", "negative scores", "application review", "full review", "new call for this proposal", "revised version", "extreme negative tone", "writing style", "another cycle", "critique 2", "same department"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Pezaris, John" <Pezaris.John@mgh.harvard.edu>
To: Gabriel Kreiman (via Google Docs) <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-01-16T16:21:00+00:00
Subject: ChatGPT's take on our reviewers

Hi Gabriel,

I asked my PO and the SRO about potential conflicts in our application review, and was sternly reassured that there were no conflicts.  Actually, I was sternly told I should not be asking about specific reviewers (I wasn't), and reassured that conflicts were checked.  I was *not* told that they had verified that there were no conflicts.

I asked ChatGPT to review the writing style of each critique and assess which member of the roster was the most likely to have written it.  This is what it came up with:

> Summary of Hypotheses
> 
>     Critique 1: Gianfranco Doretto, PhD
>     Critique 2: Ava K. Bittner, OD, PhD
>     Critique 3: Sonia Chernova, PhD
>     Critique 4: Alexandra Rae Bowers, PhD
> 
> This attribution is based on the critique's content and tone, aligned with panel member expertise and research focus. Direct > confirmation would require access to confidential review assignments.

So, although your suspicions on Alex may have been right, oddly not for Critique 3.  I tried re-reading the full review again, but it just made me angry.  I'd like to have a meeting with my PO, Cheri Wiggs, but I'm not sure what to say to her other than the reviewers were out of line.

- J.

--
John S. Pezaris, Ph.D.
Mass General Hospital / Harvard Medical School
pezaris.john@mgh.harvard.edu

The information in this e-mail is intended only for the person to whom it is addressed.  If you believe this e-mail was sent to you in error and the e-mail contains patient information, please contact the Mass General Brigham Compliance HelpLine at https://www.massgeneralbrigham.org/complianceline <https://www.massgeneralbrigham.org/complianceline> .


Message 2
From: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
To: Pezaris, John <Pezaris.John@mgh.harvard.edu>
Time: 2025-01-16T15:09:56-05:00
Subject: Re: ChatGPT's take on our reviewers

In the overall scheme of things, I do not think that the comments from Alex
Bowers are enough for our average scores.
That is, even if we remove Alex Bowers, we still got some negative scores.

I forgot the reviewer numbers. But it would be extremely difficult to
explain one of the reviewer's comments unless it was from Alex Bowers (see
my previous emails, they cited an unpublished random conference abstract
from Alex Bowers, etc., etc., etc.). I was rather surprised about her
extreme negative tone. I know Alex Bowers. I have not interacted a lot with
her, but I would not imagine any special animosity on her side. Of course,
sometimes we are rather oblivious to people who have strong feelings
against us. And the scientific comments from her were largely irrelevant.
But regardless of such feelings, I am technically in the same HMS
department as Alex Bowers. Of course, NIH always checks COIs but they rely
strongly on the PIs self-identifying those COIs. I cannot imagine how or
why Alex Bowers would not indicate a COI (I would definitely not review
papers or grants from her).
But again, even if we exclude this reviewer, there were other negative
reviews.

Cheri is great and helped us a lot with her feedback in the past. I have no
idea what can be done at this stage. I actually thought that we have a
great idea/product/proposal (though it is true that we wrote everything in
a rush). If I can help in any way, let me know. A lot of the comments are
very easy to address and change. But unless there is a new call for this
proposal and unless you are willing and able to submit a revised version
and unless we can wait for another cycle, I have no clue what could be
done. Perhaps I do not have enough imagination or understand what NIH
program officers can or cannot do.

Gabriel Kreiman

Tanto tiempo. Como va todo? De vez en cuando tuve algunas noticias tuyas
por medio de la mafia argentina en el mundo. Espero que todo este bien con
vos y tu familia.

Te escribo porque estoy empezando un start-up en el Bay-Area (Memorious) y
estamos buscando un founding software engineer. Si conoces a algunos
software engineers excelentes en el Bay Area, apreciaria si nos pones en
contacto. Mi email is gkreiman@gmail.com

Espero que nos podamos encontrar en persona pronto, especialmente ahora que
vamos a pasar mas tiempo en Bay Area.

Saludos!
Gabriel

humans with perfect and infinite memory. Es una compania de AI para
almacenar y especialmente retrieve informacion relevante para los usuarios.
Tenemos bastantes musculos en AI y ciencia. Pero estamos buscando un
founding engineer, back-end software engineer y front-end software
engineer, con experiencia en hacer software. Tenemos ya todo el codigo pero

especialmente que funcione en el mundo real.
Gracias de antemano.

Ahora estoy en Boston pero te aviso cuando este en Bay Area asi nos

Gabriel

headlines: ["I confirm sending recommendation letter for Morgan's MIT fellowship application", "Morgan requests updated recommendation letter for MIT SoE fellowships"]
anchors: ["deadline Monday March 31 at 5pm", "two different MIT School of Engineering fellowships", "recommendation letter", "finalized recommendation letter", "MIT fellowship application", "track changes version of a letter", "sent"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Morgan Talbot" <mtalbot@mit.edu>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-03-28T15:26:41-04:00
Subject: Recommendation letter request/draft for MIT fellowship

Hi Gabriel,

I am planning to apply for two different MIT School of Engineering
fellowships, per the announcement below. This would potentially cover
either 1 or 2 semesters - I am applying now because my current 1-year
fellowship expires at the end of this Spring 2025 semester. I have attached
a slightly modified (track changes) version of a letter of recommendation
you wrote for a previous fellowship application - if you have time, would
you mind taking a look at the changes and sending a finalized version to
hst-nominations@mit.edu?  *It would need to be sent by Monday March 31 at
5pm.* As always, thank you for your support in my applying for these
things.

Best,
Morgan


---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Laurie Ward <laurie@mit.edu>
Date: Thu, Mar 13, 2025 at 9:01 AM
Subject: [hst-memp] Internal Fellowships SoE applications 2025-2026 - due
3/31/25
To: hst-memp <hst-memp@mit.edu>, imes-faculty <imes-faculty@mit.edu>,
imes-senior-research <imes-senior-research@mit.edu>, hst-memp-pi <
hst-memp-pi@mit.edu>


Hi MEMP students and research supervisors,

The MIT School of Engineering (SoE) has announced its annual call for
internal fellowship nominations. Attached is a list of the fellowship
opportunities along with the required application materials. You can also
see the list *here
<https://engineering.mit.edu/students/graduate-student-fellowships/>,* without
details.

As with other MIT internal fellowships, nominations for MIT MEMP PhD
students are managed by the HST Academic Office. Because our review process
must be completed before the official SoE deadline, we ask that you submit
your application materials promptly.



Please combine all required documents into a single PDF and upload them *here
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScnvGqkRuNCgn9jSt3KKjp406UqY05380JFZqNz8b3DQ54AIQ/viewform>
*by *5:00 pm (ET), Monday, March 31*.



The Research Advisor’s letter of recommendation should be emailed directly
to *hst-nominations@mit.edu <hst-nominations@mit.edu> *by the same deadline.



We appreciate your cooperation and look forward to reviewing your
submissions. For any questions or additional information, please
contact *hst-nominations@mit.edu
<hst-nominations@mit.edu>*.

 -Laurie





*LAURIE WARD, M.Ed.*
Assistant Director, Academic Programs

*Massachusetts Institute of Technology **| Health Sciences & Technology*
77 Massachusetts Ave., E25-518 *|* Cambridge, MA 02139
phone: (617) 253-3609 *| *email:  laurie@mit.edu
https://hst.mit.edu



*In the E25-518 office: *Wednesdays and Thursdays

*Remote: *Mondays, Tuesdays, and Fridays



 *Supporting Educational Programs and Strengthening the IMES/HST Community*

[image: signature_1233438070]      [image: signature_433022488]


_______________________________________________
hst-memp mailing list
hst-memp@mit.edu
https://mailman.mit.edu/mailman/listinfo/hst-memp
