headlines: ["Andrei announces departure from MIT and move to Amazon Alexa+ role", "Andrei mentions potential for future external collaboration at Amazon", "Andrei transitions summer school responsibilities and offers further help", "I invite Andrei and his family for a farewell dinner or lunch before his departure"]
anchors: ["move to Seattle", "dinner at home", "collaborate with external folks", "transitioning summer school", "help with", "AI/ML/benchmarking", "grab lunch", "meet before you leave", "leave MIT", "principal scientist", "available online", "LLM-based Alexa+"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Andrei Barbu <andrei@0xab.com>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-06-02T13:22:29-04:00
Subject: Hey!

Hey Gabriel,

Just wanted to give you a heads up.

With kid #2 on the way, financially I just can't afford to be at MIT
anymore. Daycare is about to be like 90% of my salary. I'll be starting at
Amazon as a principal scientist heading up research for the new LLM-based
Alexa+ in July.

I'm transitioning summer school things to Brian and Morgan. Let me know if
there's anything else I can help with. I'll be available online after, but
I'll probably be physically in Seattle starting in the 2nd week of July.

It's been very fun working together, sharing students, and the summer
school!

Amazon doesn't particularly care about neuroscience research, but they do
care a lot about AI/ML/benchmarking. I'll see what it takes to collaborate
with external folks when I get there.


Thanks!
Andrei

---


Message 2
From: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
To: Andrei Barbu <andrei@0xab.com>
Time: 2025-06-02T19:52:42-04:00
Subject: Re: Hey!

Hello Andrei,

Thanks for your note.
I am sad to see you go but I understand all the constraints. I am sure that
you will conquer the world wherever you end up. I am sure that you know,
and I told you before, that you could get a faculty position anywhere in
the world that you wanted. But I also understand that this may not be the
path that you prefer.

I am sure that you are superbusy with all the changes. It would be nice to
meet before you leave. If you have time, it would be great to invite you
(plus family if you want) for dinner at home. If that is too complicated,
we can grab lunch, I can come to MIT. I am now in CA, back on Thursday.

Working with you throughout the years in the summer course and through our
collaborations has been one of the highlights of these CBMM years and I
look forward to more interactions in the future in Boston, in Seattle or
wherever life takes us.

Best,

Gabriel











On Mon, Jun 2, 2025 at 1:23 PM Andrei Barbu <andrei@0xab.com> wrote:

> Hey Gabriel,
>
> Just wanted to give you a heads up.
[...]
>
>

-- 
Gabriel Kreiman
gkreiman@gmail.com
http://klab.tch.harvard.edu

---

>

headlines: ["Align on hiring and skill development for business, demos, and communication"]
anchors: ["hire a business person", "polished and perfect decks", "videos and social media", "seek demo talent immediately", "captivating demos"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Madan, Spandan" <spandan_madan@g.harvard.edu>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-06-27T21:24:50-04:00
Subject: Demo skills

Hi Gabriel,

I was thinking, it is pretty clear that we suck at making demos. What this:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rz3LD7u2KX8. They have NOTHING, but a fancy
video/demo. Dislike the video, but point is we need very magical demos if
we want to sell to companies.

We should seriously consider how to make this happen. In the creative
world, fortunately or unfortunately, talent can be available for cheap if
we cut through the noise. I think we should dedicate time in our calendar
for this purpose very seriously.

Biggest learnings from fundraising:

1. We don't know anything about GTM/Execution of business.
2. We suck at bullshitting with confidence.
3. We suck at making captivating demos.

I think we will need to evolve on all these 3 axes to succeed in this new
life.

Would love to hear your thoughts on this! Do you have any feedback?

---
Hi Gabriel,  

  

I was thinking, it is pretty clear that we suck at making demos. What this: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rz3LD7u2KX8>. They have NOTHING, but a fancy video/demo. Dislike the video, but point is we need very magical demos if we want to sell to companies.
[...]
1\. We don't know anything about GTM/Execution of business.
2\. We suck at bullshitting with confidence.
3\. We suck at making captivating demos.
[...]


Message 2
From: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
To: Madan, Spandan <spandan_madan@g.harvard.edu>
Time: 2025-06-27T21:49:45-04:00
Subject: Re: Demo skills

I agree 100% on all 3 points.
1. We need to hire a "business person". Need to define exactly. Most
importantly, someone who is good at bs, at selling, at taking a company
from initial steps to millions. This is likely going to be one of the most
difficult but also one of the most critical hires.
2. We will learn to bs better.
3. We need to hire talent at making good demos. Let us start immediately to
seek this talent. Could be from India, Argentina, etc. if we can find
someone amazing and cheap. The key is on amazing. Making things beautiful.
We need videos. We need to be in X/LinkedIn/TikTok everywhere. We need our
decks to be polished and perfect. Everything we do needs to be beautiful,
simple, and professional.



On Fri, Jun 27, 2025 at 9:25 PM Madan, Spandan <spandan_madan@g.harvard.edu>
wrote:

> Hi Gabriel,
[...]
>


-- 
Gabriel Kreiman
gkreiman@gmail.com
http://klab.tch.harvard.edu

headlines: ["I ask Spandan to log outreach emails into shared Fundraise spreadsheet", "Spandan emails Morgan with Memorious fundraising introduction and deck"]
people: ["Madan, Spandan <spandan_madan@g.harvard.edu>", "Tom Gruber", "Hanlin Tang", "Anant Vidur Puri", "Dimitry", "I", "Morgan Cheatham <morgan@bvp.com>"]
anchors: ["Fundraise", "2X faster recall speeds", "add this and your other email", "multiple funds are committed", "92% accuracy vs 43%", "close our round in the next two weeks", "shared spreadsheet", "fundraising contacts", "Memorious Deck", "keep our spreadsheet up to date"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Madan, Spandan" <spandan_madan@g.harvard.edu>
To: 
  - Morgan Cheatham <morgan@bvp.com>
  - Mary Sullivan <msullivan@bvp.com>
  - Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-06-02T12:21:02-04:00
Subject: Harvard Professor leading AI x Human Memory startup

Hi Morgan,

I hope you’re well. Thank you again for your early feedback on our venture
last year. As promised, I’d like to introduce my co-founder, Prof. Gabriel
Kreiman—a Harvard Medical School professor with 30+ years in AI and human
memory. *He is shutting down his tenured lab at Harvard to lead
Memorious **full-time.
*Our vision is to create *superhumans* by endowing humanity with perfect,
infinite memory.

Our slide deck is attached. We would love to share more over a call if
there is interest. We met several VCs in Palo Alto this week, and multiple
funds are committed. Anant Vidur Puri spoke very highly of you, so we
wanted to see if you’d be interested as we close our round in the next two
weeks.

*A blurb about our venture:*


*Memorious* is your personal memory companion designed to augment human
memory using AI. Everything you read, every person you meet, and every
conversation you have—all *instantly accessible without any search or
prompts*. Using Ambient Intelligence, we spontaneously surface your
memories exactly when you need them. Superhuman memory, powered by AI.


Our privacy-first technology outperforms standard AI: *92% accuracy vs 43%
for LLMs like OpenAI* and *2X faster recall speeds*. In the $3B+ brain
training and wellness app market, we're reimagining human memory with AI to
give everyone perfect, infinite recall.


*Leadership:* Dr. Gabriel Kreiman, Harvard Medical School Professor
specializing in AI and human memory, and Dr. Spandan Madan, Harvard AI
researcher with a decade of deep-learning systems experience. Our advisory
board includes Tom Gruber (Co-Founder and CTO, Siri Inc.) and Hanlin
Tang (Co-Founder
and CTO, MosaicML).


Thank you for your time,
Spandan

---
**Leadership :** Dr. Gabriel Kreiman, Harvard Medical School Professor specializing in AI and human memory, and Dr. Spandan Madan, Harvard AI researcher with a decade of deep-learning systems experience. Our advisory board includes Tom Gruber (Co-Founder and CTO, Siri Inc.) and Hanlin Tang  __(Co-Founder and CTO, MosaicML).
[...]

headlines: ["Consent to share contact details for QS Academic Reputation Survey"]
topics: ["QS Global Academic Survey participation for Tel Aviv University"]
anchors: ["consent to share contact information", "QS Intelligence Unit", "Academic Reputation Index", "survey participation confirmation", "QS Global Academic Survey"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Adi Feuermann <adidi@tauex.tau.ac.il>
To: gkreiman@gmail.com <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-01-07T10:53:02+00:00
Subject: QS Academic Reputation Survey

Dear Prof. Gabriel Kreiman,

Warm greetings!

I am reaching out to you in recognition of your record of collaboration with Tel Aviv University (TAU).  Given your academic commitments and your familiarity with us, we want to invite you to evaluate TAU as part of the QS Global Academic Survey. This would entail passing along your contact information (name, job title, institution, email address) to the QS Intelligence Unit (QSIU), who would then contact you over the next few months to participate in the survey.

If you consent to us sending along your information to QSIU, could you let us know by January 20th ?  If we do NOT hear back from you, we will assume you do not want to participate as a respondent in the survey this year.

If you do agree to participate, your responses, in combination with responses from other global survey participants, will help to determine the next iteration of the QS World University rankings (including at the global, regional, subject and programme levels, where relevant) and will specifically inform the Academic Reputation Index<https://support.qs.com/hc/en-gb/articles/4405952675346-Academic-Reputation>.

Please note:

  *   QSIU will email you the survey request from the email address rankings@qs.com<mailto:rankings@qs.com>. QSIU typically sends one invitation, along with a maximum of two reminders. We recommend adding rankings@qs.com<mailto:rankings@qs.com> as a safe sender to avoid having the email identified as spam.
  *   Surveys are typically distributed in the first quarter each year, so we recommend looking out for emails from QSIU in February or March.
  *   All survey data will be used in aggregate form.
  *   You will not be contacted by QSIU for more than two editions of their survey.
  *   QSIU will not contact you for any other reason without supplementary or separate consent.

Thank you again for your collaboration and partnership with TAU, and wishing you a happy 2025!


Sincerely,


[A group of black circles with white text  Description automatically generated]
Professor Milette Shamir
Vice President, International
Tel Aviv University
p: +972(03)640-5224 m: +972-54-7670775
a: Minhala Building 304, Tel Aviv, Israel 6997801
w: https://english.tau.ac.il/profile/mshamir

headlines: ["Request for remaining interview audio recordings upload", "Request to facilitate introduction to CareYaya CEO"]
anchors: ["Drive folder", "CareYaya introduction", "CEO connection", "research interview transcripts", "short write-up", "remaining recordings", "audio files"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Madan, Spandan" <spandan_madan@g.harvard.edu>
To: Stone, Dezarae Rose <dstone@unc.edu>
Time: 2025-04-14T16:35:30-04:00
Subject: Follow-up on Interview files and Introduction

Hi Dezarae,

Hope you're doing well and that your grad school applications went
smoothly! Did you decide which program you will be joining?

I wanted to follow up on a couple of things:

1. Research Interview Transcripts: I checked the Drive folder (
https://drive.google.com/drive/u/1/folders/1Q4fM0UPbN_NmB0ZZLiwhmsbBELyDFiX1)
and saw about seven transcripts there. I recall the original plan was to
complete around 20 interviews—were all of them conducted? If so, could you
upload the remaining recordings? Transcription isn’t necessary; we’re happy
to handle that ourselves. It would be really helpful to get access to the
audio files as soon as possible.

2. CareYaya Introduction: Earlier in the project, you had mentioned the
possibility of connecting us with the CEO of CareYaya. Would that still be
feasible? We’ve made substantial progress on our end and would love the
opportunity to share our work and get his feedback. Happy to share a
short-write up about our work if that will help you set up the introduction
email.

Thanks so much, and looking forward to hearing from you!

Warmly,
Spandan

Hi Gabriel,

I was wondering if you would like to submit a poster for the Frontiers in NeuroAI symposium Kempner is putting together. https://kempnerinstitute.harvard.edu/frontiers-in-neuroai/

Thanks!

Elisa

headlines: ["Pause LLaVa experiments and switch unified model to GPT-4o"]
anchors: ["free viewing task", "pause LLaVa-related experiments", "GPT-4o", "zero-shot and few-shot ICL", "unified model"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Liu Xiao <liuxiao@u.nus.edu>
To: Pavarino, Elisa Catherine <epavarino@fas.harvard.edu>
Time: 2025-02-20T10:59:21+00:00
Subject: Pause LLaVa exps

Hi Elisa,

As LLaVa still failed to do free viewing task (no matter zero-shot or few-shot ICL) and we figured out GPT-4o can do so (not perfectly but still much better than LLaVa's nonsense responses), we decided to change the unified model to GPT-4o.
Please pause LLaVa-related experiments to save time and let's discuss next Monday. Sorry for any inconvenience!!

Best Regards,
Liu Xiao

headlines: ["Dimi forwards Memorious deck to several VCs and asks for fundraise status", "Spandan requests Dimi\u2019s warm VC introductions for Memorious fundraise"]
anchors: ["forwarded the deck to a few VCs", "waiting to hear back", "multiple funds are committed", "Memorious slide deck attachment", "status of the fundraise", "warm introductions to relevant VCs", "closing the funding round in the next 2 weeks"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Madan, Spandan" <spandan_madan@g.harvard.edu>
To: 
  - Dimitri.kellari@gmail.com
  - Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-06-02T12:36:27-04:00
Subject: Introducing Memorious: Reimagining human memory using AI

Dear Dimi,

Thank you for graciously offering to help us with Memorious. I’d like to
introduce my co-founder, Prof. Gabriel Kreiman—a Harvard Medical School
professor with 30+ years in AI and human memory. *He is shutting down his
tenured lab at Harvard to lead Memorious **full-time. *Our vision is to
create *superhumans* by endowing humanity with perfect, infinite memory.

Our slide deck is attached. We met several VCs in Palo Alto this week, and
multiple funds are committed. We plan on closing the funding round in the
next 2 weeks, so any warm introductions to relevant VCs in your network
would be greatly appreciated!

*A blurb about our venture:*

*Memorious* is your personal memory companion designed to augment human
memory using AI. Everything you read, every person you meet, and every
conversation you have—all *instantly accessible without any search or
prompts*. Using Ambient Intelligence, we spontaneously surface your
memories exactly when you need them. Superhuman memory, powered by AI.


Our privacy-first technology outperforms standard AI: *92% accuracy vs 43%
for LLMs like OpenAI* and *2X faster recall speeds*. In the $3B+ brain
training and wellness app market, we're reimagining human memory with AI to
give everyone perfect, infinite recall.


*Leadership:* Dr. Gabriel Kreiman, Harvard Medical School Professor
specializing in AI and human memory, and Dr. Spandan Madan, Harvard AI
researcher with a decade of deep-learning systems experience. Our advisory
board includes Tom Gruber (Co-Founder and CTO, Siri Inc.) and Hanlin
Tang (Co-Founder
and CTO, MosaicML).


Thank you for your time,
Spandan

---

---

full_content:
Message 1
From: "Zhang Mengmi (Asst Prof)" <mengmi.zhang@ntu.edu.sg>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-09-23T14:06:30+00:00
Subject: Fw: Research Collaboration on Dog Vocalization Study

FYI; sorting out a common meeting slot when you come.

Best,

Mengmi
Nanyang assistant professor and PI of Deep NeuroCognition Lab
College of Computing and Data Science
Nanyang Technological University
Lab website: https://a0091624.wixsite.com/deepneurocognition-1

________________________________
From: Zhang Mengmi (Asst Prof) <mengmi.zhang@ntu.edu.sg>
Sent: Tuesday, September 23, 2025 1:47 PM
To: Pawsforcause sg <info@pawsforcause.sg>
Subject: Re: Research Collaboration on Dog Vocalization Study

Hi Suzy,
Thank you for your reply!
As this project involves a research collaborator (Prof. Gabriel Kreiman from Harvard University) who will visit Singapore starting Oct 15 until November 6, would it be possible to move the meeting and on-site visit to that date (e.g. Oct 15, 10am-7pm)?
Thanks, and we look forward to seeing you!

Best,

Mengmi
Nanyang assistant professor and PI of Deep NeuroCognition Lab
College of Computing and Data Science
Nanyang Technological University
Lab website: https://a0091624.wixsite.com/deepneurocognition-1
________________________________
From: Pawsforcause sg <info@pawsforcause.sg>
Sent: Tuesday, September 23, 2025 9:04 AM
To: Zhang Mengmi (Asst Prof) <mengmi.zhang@ntu.edu.sg>
Subject: Re: Research Collaboration on Dog Vocalization Study


[Alert:
 Non-NTU Email] Be cautious before clicking any link or attachment.

Hi Mengmi,

Apologies for my late reply.

Thanks for contacting me about collaboration opportunities. I would be very keen to find out more about your project and how we can be part of it. Do you think we can arrange an on-site visit and meeting sometime during  6th to 8th Oct?

I look forward to hearing from you.

Best Regards

Suzy Gow
PAWS FOR CAUSE (AVS approved agent)
(65) 88600020
[cid:ii_19974176d0c01]




On Thu, 11 Sept 2025 at 13:54, Zhang Mengmi (Asst Prof) <mengmi.zhang@ntu.edu.sg<mailto:mengmi.zhang@ntu.edu.sg>> wrote:
Dear  Paws For Cause Team,
My name is Mengmi Zhang, Assistant Professor in College of Computing and Data Science at NTU. Our team plans to study dog vocalizations in naturalistic settings using Artificial Intelligence (AI), collecting visual and audio recordings to better understand how dogs communicate.
We are planning to apply for a research grant next year (e.g., AI for Science / CRP) to support this work and are very interested in a research collaboration with you. We would love to arrange a short meeting and on-site visit to discuss whether it’s possible to collect recordings at your facility in a non-intrusive, welfare-friendly way.
We would acknowledge your support in publications and share research insights that may benefit your work with dogs.
Please let us know if you are open to research collaborations. Thank you for your time, and we look forward to your reply.


Best,

Mengmi
Nanyang assistant professor and PI of Deep NeuroCognition Lab
College of Computing and Data Science
Nanyang Technological University
Lab website: https://a0091624.wixsite.com/deepneurocognition-1

headlines: ["Cell Press confirms paper acceptance and outlines production and proof timeline"]
anchors: ["accession number or Mendeley data", "paper has been copyedited", "proof corrections due within 1 business day", "receive proofs within 3 business days", "sent to suppliers to be typeset"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Bryndzia, Layla (ELS-HBE)" <lbryndzia@cell.com>
To: 
  - gabriel.kreiman@tch.harvard.edu <gabriel.kreiman@tch.harvard.edu>
  - gkreiman@gmail.com <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-03-07T17:00:33+00:00
Subject: Cell Reports Publication Information (CELREP 115429)

Dear Dr. Kreiman,

Congratulations on your paper's acceptance for publication with Cell Press! My name is Layla, and I will be handling your paper through the proof stage. I'm writing to let you know that your paper has been copyedited and sent off to our suppliers to be typeset. Below is the remaining production timeline:

o       You will receive proofs within the next 3 business days
o       Your proofs will include some standard queries that we ask of all authors as well as some specific questions that came up during copyediting
o       All proof corrections will be due within 1 business day of receipt to ensure quick publication; please let me know if you foresee any difficulties with this timeframe.
o       Your paper will be published online within a few days of your proofs being finalized*

            *Does your paper include a newly reported accession number or have you deposited any data on Mendeley<https://nam11.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdata.mendeley.com%2F&data=05%7C01%7Clshipp%40cell.com%7C16a97dd041ad4785401408da3e899cd0%7C9274ee3f94254109a27f9fb15c10675d%7C0%7C0%7C637891058036174715%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=2iJRvhIfmrotHrjTaeYcD8%2FHVaADQENtIosD35wqow8%3D&reserved=0>? Please ensure that the data will be released for public viewing as soon as possible.

If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to ask. Please retain your manuscript number (in the subject line) in all communications with the production team. Thank you in advance for your prompt return of the proofs!

All the best,

Layla Bryndzia (she/her)
Deputy Production Editor
American Journal of Human Genetics | HGG Advances
lbryndzia@cell.com<mailto:lbryndzia@cell.com>






---

Message 1
From: Boris Katz <boris@csail.mit.edu>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-08-13T19:28:58-04:00
Subject: Haim's second lecture

Hi Gabriel,

At dinner tonight, Haim stopped by to tell me that he had a version of the BMM schedule showing him teaching tomorrow from 3pm to 5pm, and that he is upset because we had changed it and only offered him one time slot. I told him he probably made a mistake, but since he was upset, I suggested we find another time slot for his second lecture. He plans to talk about language.

We do have a slot available on Friday at 3pm, and I’d like to offer it to Haim. Hope it’s OK with you.

Thank you.

Boris



---

Friday 3pm is not good for Haim probably because of Shabat, he likes to end
Fridays early.
I don't thin that we ever had 3-5pm.
In any case, now that Winrich is not coming, we have more time on Thursday.
We can ask Ueli to speak a little later and give some more time to Haim if
he needs it.

Subject: Please submit the Meta-Review for AAAI 2026 no later than October 28

Dear Prof Gabriel Kreiman,

I hope this message finds you well.

I noticed that the meta-reviews for some of your assigned papers have not
yet been submitted. As the SPC meta-reviews and recommendations were due on
October 24, I would like to kindly ask if you could submit your pending
meta-reviews by October 28. This would greatly help keep the review process
on track.

Thank you very much for your time and valuable contributions.

Best regards,
Hung-yi Lee

Time: 2025-04-14T11:29:38+02:00
Subject: NSF GRFP fellowship summary report-discussion and signature request

Dear Gabriel,

I hope this email finds you well. As you know, every year I have to do an
annual report for the nsf people about what I have accomplished/learned for
the year. I have attached my report and the form that you are to fill out
if you want to approve it. Instructions are that I discuss my report with
you before you sign (I copied/pasted the instructions below), so happy to
do that this coming Wednesday for our 1-on-1 meeting. I will be there in
person. The deadline to sign this in April 25th, so we have time to do
this.

Thank you in advance,
Dianna

headlines: ["Approval to explore external collaboration on What Neural Networks Don't Know"]
anchors: ["first author", "external collaboration", "potential collaborator", "authorship order"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Gabriel Baca Rubinztain <gabrielbacar@gmail.com>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-04-10T10:02:39-03:00
Subject: Pregunta Rápida Sobre Colaboración para What Neural Networks Don't Know

Hola profesor!

Gracias por el tiempo hoy. Creo que parte de lo que hice se puede llevar a
redes más grandes, tengo varias ideas.

La verdad que no conozco muy bien cómo funciona el etiquette en
investigación así que te quería preguntar si estaría bien potencialmente
colaborar con alguien más en el proyecto.

El otro día conocí a un chico de la UNLP que presentó en NeurIPS el año
pasado (es segundo autor en https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.14506 ). Le comenté
un poco lo que hacía y mostró un poco de interés en potencialmente
colaborar.

Te quería preguntar si esto estaría bien para tí explorar alguna
colaboración o prefieres mantenerlo cerrado.

Saludos!

Gabriel Baca Rubinztain

---
El otro día conocí a un chico de la UNLP que presentó en NeurIPS el año pasado (es segundo autor en <https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.14506> ). Le comenté un poco lo que hacía y mostró un poco de interés en potencialmente colaborar. 
[...]


Message 2
From: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
To: Gabriel Baca Rubinztain <gabrielbacar@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-04-10T10:34:55-04:00
Subject: Re: Pregunta Rápida Sobre Colaboración para What Neural Networks Don't Know

No hay problema de mi parte.
Para evitar potenciales malesentendidos, una cosa que podes hacer es
clarificar quien seria autor, orden de autores, etc. para que no haya
falsas expectativas. Por ejemplo, podes conversar con el sobre la
posibilidad colaborar pero aclararle que vos serias el primer autor, etc.

gabrielbacar@gmail.com> wrote:

full_content:
Message 1
From: Tomaso Poggio <tp@csail.mit.edu>
To: 
  - James DiCarlo <dicarlo@mit.edu>
  - Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
  - Josh Tenenbaum <josh.tenenbaum@gmail.com>
  - Boris Katz <boris@mit.edu>
  - Nancy Kanwisher <ngk@mit.edu>
  - Kenneth Blum <kenneth_blum@harvard.edu>
Time: 2025-08-18T11:37:58-04:00
Subject: Re: interest in CBMM award supplement for partnerships workshop?

All,

NSF would like to give a six month extension of CBMM in order to 
organize a workshop  on Center non-academic partnerships, with an 
emphasis on industry and foundations and other non-profits (see original 
msg from Rebecca below). The workshop over ~2 days -- in person -- would 
involve ~3 people from each STC center (there are 9-14 STCs potentially 
interested) plus representative from outside partners and we would pay 
for travel etc.. We would get around 150K and we would have to write a 
brief proposal before Sept 1. The extension  cannot be more than 6 
months --  therefore until the end of February.

I think the idea is good from the point of view of STCs but I am 
inclined to say no, unless I hear otherwise from you! I promised to 
answer towards the end of the week.

best
tommy

partnerships workshop?

From: 	Morss, Rebecca E. <reellis@nsf.gov>
To: 	Tomaso Poggio <tp@csail.mit.edu>



Hi- You can reach me at 303-359-6710.

Best,

Rebecca

*Sent:* Friday, August 15, 2025 4:24 PM
*To:* Morss, Rebecca E. <reellis@nsf.gov>
*Subject:* Re: [EXTERNAL] - Re: interest in CBMM award supplement for 
partnerships workshop?

10:30 is ok! Which number should I call?

T

Sent from my iPhone



    On Aug 15, 2025, at 2:39 PM, Morss, Rebecca E. <reellis@nsf.gov> wrote:

    ﻿

    Great! I’m available at 10:30 or 11 on Monday. Or if that doesn’t
    work, I could meet early or late in the day.

    Best,

    Rebecca

    *From:*Tomaso Poggio <tp@csail.mit.edu>
    *Sent:* Friday, August 15, 2025 12:34 PM
    *To:* Morss, Rebecca E. <reellis@nsf.gov>
    *Subject:* [EXTERNAL] - Re: interest in CBMM award supplement for
    partnerships workshop?


    	

    This email originated from outside of the National Science
    Foundation. Do not click links or open attachments unless you
    recognize the sender and know the content is safe.

    Rebecca.

    we could speak on Monday on the phone if you have time!

    tomaso

    On 8/15/25 2:21 PM, Morss, Rebecca E. wrote:

        Hi,

        Dragana Brzakovic retired in March, and I am now managing the
        NSF STC program. The program is interested funding a supplement
        to one of the STCs to design and implement a workshop on Center
        non-academic partnerships, with an emphasis on industry and
        foundations and other non-profits. The general goal would be to
        discuss different STCs’ and partners’ perspectives and
        experiences, in order to share knowledge among the STCs
        (especially for the newer STCs) and with the STC program. Given
        CBMM’s experience with these types of partnerships, we thought
        the Center would be well-suited for this effort.

        Phil Regalia said that CBMM is on a no-cost extension that ends
        on Aug 31, and so the timeline on moving forward is short.
        Please let me know whether you and/or others at CBMM are
        potentially interested. If so, I can answer any questions and we
        can set up a time for a quick conversation. And if not, thank
        you for considering this, and we’ll reach out to another Center.

        Best,

        Rebecca

        ---

        Rebecca E. Morss, PhD

        Program Director, Science and Technology Centers: Integrative
        Partnerships
        <https://www.nsf.gov/funding/opportunities/science-technology-centers-integrative-partnerships/nsf22-521/solicitation>
        & Growing Convergence Research
        <https://www.nsf.gov/funding/opportunities/gcr-growing-convergence-research>
        programs

        Office of Integrative Activities

        U.S. National Science Foundation

    -- 

    ---------------------------------------

    Tomaso Poggio

    Eugene McDermott Professor

    co-Director NSF Science & Technology Center for Brains,

    Minds and Machines(CBMM)http://cbmm.mit.edu/

    McGovern Institute

    Brain Sciences Department

    Web:http://cbcl.mit.edu/people/poggio/poggio-new.htm

    PoggioLab Web page:http://cbcl.mit.edu/

All,
  

NSF would like to give a six month extension of CBMM in order to organize a workshop on Center non-academic partnerships, with an emphasis on industry and foundations and other non-profits (see original msg from Rebecca below). The workshop over ~2 days -- in person -- would involve ~3 people from each STC center (there are 9-14 STCs potentially interested) plus representative from outside partners and we would pay for travel etc.. We would get around 150K and we would have to write a brief proposal before Sept 1. The extension cannot be more than 6 months -- therefore until the end of February.

On Thu, May 08, 2025 at 10:44 AM, Gabriel Kreiman < gkreiman@gmail.com > wrote:

> 
> Yes, we are very familiar with Rewind, now rebranded as limitless. It's an
> interesting effort but there are many differences.
> 
> 
> (1) They have a "nuclear" approach to record the screen, now they added a
> pendant to record audio. They do not have direct integration to build the
> memorome across different applications as we do.
> (2) They do traditional search, they are not really building episodic
> memory representations like our algorithms do.
> (3) Not sure what their main target is but they are not trying to help
> people with memory decline like we do.
> (4) Most critically, they do not have ambient intelligence, which is the
> key to memory recall in humans.
> 
> 
> There are lots of companies that summarize and store information like they
> do. The key issue is how to effectively use the information to make it
> available when needed and useful. That is what distinguishes us.

full_content:
Message 1
From: nihms-help@ncbi.nlm.nih.gov
To: 
  - gabriel.kreiman@tch.harvard.edu
  - gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-03-26T04:35:15
Subject: NIHMS2069127: Please review manuscript submission

Dear Gabriel Kreiman,

Your action is required for submission of a manuscript to the NIH Manuscript Submission (NIHMS) system for inclusion in PubMed Central (PMC).  

Elsevier has submitted the following in compliance with a PMC-participating funder's public access policy (see https://www.nihms.nih.gov/about/publicaccess) and designated you as the Reviewer:

Journal name: Cell reports
Manuscript title: Neural correlates of minimal recognizable configurations in the human brain
Manuscript ID: NIHMS2069127

This process applies to research funded only by those listed at https://www.nihms.nih.gov/about/funders. If the research was not funded by one of these agencies, please let us know. Otherwise, please be sure to associate or confirm any relevant funding support prior to approving the deposited materials. Applicable funding must be associated in the NIHMS system even if it was also acknowledged in the manuscript text.

1. Go to the NIHMS login page by clicking on the following link:

  https://www.nihms.nih.gov/submission/review/?token=A3QI4LX74D

**You must follow this link to find your manuscript.** If the above link is broken, please copy and paste the entire URL into your browser. The link is a "ticket" that allows the NIHMS system to match the manuscript with your login session.

Your ticket number is A3QI4LX74D.

2. Log in to the NIHMS system. If you need assistance logging in, step-by-step tutorials are available at https://www.nihms.nih.gov/help/tutorials.
  
3. Review the submission using the guidance provided in the interactive "walkthrough" and either confirm it is complete or reject it with comments. (Only an author or a PI should serve as the Reviewer of an NIHMS submission. Not an author or a PI? Designate another Reviewer in the Reviewer and Release Delay [Embargo] section of the submission record.)

Upon submission approval, the manuscript will be prepared for archiving in PMC. This conversion process typically takes 2 to 3 weeks but varies depending on Reviewer responsiveness and the volume of submissions during a given period. You will be notified via email when the PMC-ready documents are ready for review (see https://www.nihms.nih.gov/about/overview#process).

For additional assistance, please reply to this email.

Thank you,

The NIHMS Help Desk

Hi Gabriel,

A quick update about inviting lecturers to BMM-2025. Not much progress, unfortunately:

Leslie Kaelbling told me she needed time to coordinate with Vikash and Nancy and asked when we needed to have this nailed down. I replied that we have to know by the end of the month.

Tommy said that he needed more time to decide.

Marc Raibert and Dorin Comaniciu haven’t responded yet.

Daniela said that she is away in August.

And I believe I told you already that Aude Oliva will also be away.

Is your progress any better? Have you heard from Sam and Winrich?

I see that Stefanie Tellex is still in italics. Do you want me to invite her?

Thank you.

Boris

Message 1
From: Daniel Weisholtz <dweisholtz@gmail.com>
To: gkreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-07-30T13:41:51-04:00
Subject: grant updated drafts and next steps

Hi Gabriel,

I am attaching updated drafts of the specific aims and the research
strategy. As we are now moving into August, I'd love to meet again in the
short term, even before you have had a chance to review these documents, to
discuss next steps.  I would like to talk about what mechanisms to apply
for, how to find other opportunities, and how to get started with the next
steps.

What I have seen so far is this one, which you sent me a few years back,
but it still seems active:
https://grants.nih.gov/grants/guide/pa-files/PAR-25-291.html
It does talk about mental disorders in the RFA, and this proposal is about
anxiety in epilepsy. I wonder if it's worth trying to play up the relevance
for anxiety disorders in general.

I also think it makes sense to apply for a K01, K08, K23, or K99/R00.  I
found this one:
https://grants.nih.gov/grants/guide/pa-files/PAR-25-215.html

This one sounds vaguely relevant, but seems to be about developing new
recording or neuromodulation technologies.
https://grants.nih.gov/grants/guide/rfa-files/RFA-NS-24-031.html

Please let me know what your availability is like in the next few weeks.
Many thanks.

Best,
Dan

Hi founders,
We need to get a time for our next milestone meeting with the Innovation Committee/Board.
I’ve got 20 day/time combos to choose from in mid-June for our Q2 Milestone Meeting. Please try to fill this out asap so we can land a time. As usual, the meeting will be on zoom. Please be sure to check all that you can attend. You don’t need to be available for the entire 2 hours, just a 20 min segment.
FYI – Sportsbuddy and Business of Science (and all of cohort 1) have moved to alumni status and will not present at this meeting. But that gives you more time! 😊

Here’s the doodle poll<https://doodle.com/group-poll/participate/avLgRr8d> to fill out. Thanks.
Please advise if you have any questions!
Hope everyone is doing well.
Best
Debi


Debi Kleiman | Director, AI Lab for Startups @ the Institute for Quantitative Social Science<https://www.iq.harvard.edu/> | HARVARD UNIVERSITY

headlines: ["Plan decision timeline for MIT J-WEL Education Innovation Grant application", "Suggest additional HMS contacts to follow up about DIA and grant renewal"]
anchors: ["decision this Wednesday", "extend or renew HMS grant", "MIT faculty PI", "Slack channel for grant awardees", "departmental letter of support", "researchinitiatives", "email Rosalind Segal", "forwarding to additional addresses", "grant funding", "deansinitiatives"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Morgan Talbot" <mtalbot@mit.edu>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-01-27T09:55:47-05:00
Subject: Grants followup

Hi Gabriel,

I hope you have enjoyed the weekend. I wanted to check in with you about
our grants situation, given that the deadline for the MIT J-WEL Education
Innovation Grant <https://www.jwel.mit.edu/grants> ($20K-80K) is coming up
next Wednesday Feb 5th. If we are applying, we would need to plan somewhat
in advance because we would need to get Jim directly involved (we'd need an
MIT faculty member to be listed as the PI) and also obtain a departmental
"letter of support" before the deadline.

Have you heard back anything yet about extending/renewing our HMS grant,
and/or have you had a chance to review the current state of our grant
funding? Any thoughts on whether we should go ahead and pursue the J-WEL
grant?

Best,
Morgan
-- 
*Morgan Talbot *(he/him)
MD-PhD Candidate, Harvard/MIT Health Sciences and Technology (HST)
mtalbot@mit.edu

---
Hi Gabriel,  
  
I hope you have enjoyed the weekend. I wanted to check in with you about our grants situation, given that the deadline for the [MIT J-WEL Education Innovation Grant](https://www.jwel.mit.edu/grants) ($20K-80K) is coming up next Wednesday Feb 5th. If we are applying, we would need to plan somewhat in advance because we would need to get Jim directly involved (we'd need an MIT faculty member to be listed as the PI) and also obtain a departmental "letter of support" before the deadline.   
[...]
\--   

**Morgan Talbot**(he/him)  
MD-PhD Candidate, Harvard/MIT Health Sciences and Technology (HST)
[mtalbot@mit.edu](mailto:mtalbot@mit.edu)

From: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
To: Morgan Talbot <mtalbot@mit.edu>
Time: 2025-01-27T10:02:24-05:00
Subject: Re: Grants followup

I emailed them last Thursday after our conversation. I used the two emails
that you sent me. I cc-ed you. I have not heard from them. Was there anyone
else involved in the DIA that we could reach out to?

When you say "departmental", I assume that you mean MIT/BCS, right?

Let's give them one or two more days to reply and we make a decision this
Wednesday, ok?

To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-01-27T10:14:05-05:00
Subject: Re: Grants followup

I saw the email - thank you again for sending it and for this update. In
addition to the email addresses we sent to initially, we could *also* try
forwarding it to "*deansinitiatives@hms.harvard.edu
<deansinitiatives@hms.harvard.edu>*" and "*researchinitiatives@hms.harvard.edu
<researchinitiatives@hms.harvard.edu>*." We could also potentially email
Rosalind Segal (Dean for Graduate Education, *rosalind_segal@dfci.harvard.edu
<rosalind_segal@dfci.harvard.edu>*) - unsure precisely how she is involved
with the grants, but seemingly is in some way because she created the slack
channel for grant awardees.

To clarify about the "departmental letter": yes, probably from MIT BCS. the
website says if multiple MIT departments are involved, a letter from any of
them can suffice - so potentially a letter from the HST dept. could also
work.

Deciding on wednesday sounds good to me - thanks again!

headlines: ["Gabriel Baca Rubinztain shares updated paper draft and pipeline figure option", "I provide revision guidance for the What Neural Networks Know paper", "I send ChatGPT-generated acronym name suggestions for the method"]
anchors: ["checklist for the paper", "acronym options", "method name suggestions", "data-free inference", "quantitative part weaker", "finalized paper version", "latent knowledge", "overleaf comments", "large pipeline figure", "name for the method", "comments and suggestions", "pipeline figure"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Gabriel Baca Rubinztain <gabrielbacar@gmail.com>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-11-12T01:38:26-03:00
Subject: What Neural Networks Know: Final draft ready?

Hola profesor!

He estado metiendo bastante duro al paper. As of today ya estaría
finalizada la versión del paper que incluye todo tus comentarios.

Creo que la parte más floja es la cuantitativa, pero no tuve mucho tiempo
para sacar más datos concretos.

Quería originalmente hacer una figura grande que mostrara el pipeline del
experimento pero por temas de espacio estoy optando por no ponerla. Si
consideras que es importante podría hacerla y colocarla mañana.

Estoy pendiente a cualquier cambio o sugerencia para hacerlo mañana.

Saludos,
Gabriel

---


Message 2
From: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
To: Gabriel Baca Rubinztain <gabrielbacar@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-11-12T07:12:59-05:00
Subject: Re: What Neural Networks Know: Final draft ready?

(1) Seria util si hay tiempo agregar una figura con un pipeline si es
posible
(2) Queres ponerle un nombre al metodo? Es usual eso en AI y es
mas facil para recordar y para no tener que escribir "our method". En
general, el nombre son siglas de varias palabras.
(3) Hace falta un checklist para el paper? Fijate en las instrucciones. Me
han rechazado un paper anteriormente por no incluir el checklist required.
Pero me parece que eso era NeurIPS, no CVPR.
(4) See more comments in overleaf. I am flying soon, will try to read more
when I can.

gabrielbacar@gmail.com> wrote:

Message 3
From: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
To: Gabriel Baca Rubinztain <gabrielbacar@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-11-12T07:20:21-05:00
Subject: Re: What Neural Networks Know: Final draft ready?

My friend ChatGPT suggested:


   -

   *CULI* — *Covert Uncovering of Latent Information*
   -

   *PEEK* — *Prototype-based Extraction of Encoded Knowledge*
   -

   *SCOPE* — *Semantic Class Optimization for Prototype Extraction*
   -

   *REVEAL* — *Representation Evaluation via Emergent Alignment Learning*
   -

   *LUCID* — *Latent Uncovering through Class-Informed Distillation*

------------------------------
🧠 2. Acronyms emphasizing *latent knowledge* and *data-free inference*

   -

   *KNOW* — *Knowledge Neuron Observation without Weights (data)*
   -

   *DEEP* — *Data-free Extraction of Encoded Prototypes*
   -

   *CLEAR* — *Class-Level Embedding Alignment and Recovery*
   -

   *PROBE* — *Prototype-based Representation Of Base Embeddings*
   -

   *INSIGHT* — *Inferring Network Semantics via Generated Hierarchical
   Taxonomies*

------------------------------
🔬 3. Acronyms highlighting *privacy, safety, and interpretability*

   -

   *PRISM* — *Privacy-Respecting Inference of Semantic Models*
   -

   *SHADE* — *Semantic Hallucination for Attribute Discovery and Evaluation*
   -

   *TRACE* — *Training Reconstruction and Concept Extraction*
   -

   *SAFE* — *Self-Aligned Feature Extraction*
   -

   *GLOW* — *Generating Latent Observations Without data*

------------------------------
💡 4. More playful or catchy options

   -

   *DREAM* — *Data-free Representation Extraction and Alignment Method*
   -

   *SPARK* — *Self-Probing Analysis of Represented Knowledge*
   -

   *MIRROR* — *Model-Internal Representation Reconstruction and Observation
   Routine*
   -

   *PHASE* — *Prototype Hallucination for Attribute SEmantics*
   -

   *MUSE* — *Model Understanding via Synthesized Embeddings*

Message 1
From: "Kleiman, Debi" <dkleiman@iq.harvard.edu>

  - carmen@vie.science <carmen@vie.science>

  - rebecca@globalhealthdelivery.org <rebecca@globalhealthdelivery.org>
Time: 2025-04-07T15:02:14+00:00
Subject: Linkedin training

Hi Founders!
Hope everyone had a nice weekend.
I’m offering a workshop on using linkedin to help your startup. We’ll cover creating your profile, posting and networking. Last time we did this the teams found it to be hugely helpful – so please make an effort to attend.
Does Monday afternoon April 28th work for you? 2-3:30 pm EST.
Please lmk.
Thanks
Debi


Debi Kleiman | Director, AI Lab for Startups @ the Institute for Quantitative Social Science<https://www.iq.harvard.edu/> | HARVARD UNIVERSITY

Message 1

Subject: Thesis Before Final Submission

Dear Gabriel,

I wanted to share the final version of the thesis before I submit it to the
registrar.

https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/okvx7rkhs0aqd6gt5to16/PranavMisraThesisCombined.pdf?rlkey=ilxhwnlvtpagtilhyu1x35pdt&dl=0

Dear Gabriel, 
  

I wanted to share the final version of the thesis before I submit it to the registrar.
  

[https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/okvx7rkhs0aqd6gt5to16/PranavMisraThesisCombined.pdf?rlkey=ilxhwnlvtpagtilhyu1x35pdt&dl=0](https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/okvx7rkhs0aqd6gt5to16/PranavMisraThesisCombined.pdf?rlkey=ilxhwnlvtpagtilhyu1x35pdt&dl=0)
  

Could you please have a look at it in case you'd like me to make any edits before I send it?
  

Best,
Pranav


Message 2
From: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
To: Pranav Misra <misra.pranav@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-03-23T12:31:04-04:00
Subject: Re: Thesis Before Final Submission

Hello Pranav,

I am not sure what you changed. One of the main changes that you had to
make is that Venki had indicated that you had to explain what your
contribution was to each part of the work. I do not see that anywhere. Can
you point me to where you incorporated Venki's feedback?

Gabriel Kreiman

Message 3
From: Pranav Misra <misra.pranav@gmail.com>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-03-23T20:44:19-04:00
Subject: Re: Thesis Before Final Submission

Hello Gabriel,

So, Venki suggested two edits:

   1. Mentioning that the surgeries were done by neurosurgeons, to make it
   clear that I was not involved in the surgery aspect of the research. I
   added these changes on page 109.

Message 1
From: Karaka Prasanth Naidu <prasanthnaidu31k@gmail.com>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-01-25T11:22:18+05:30
Subject: Regarding Relevant Papers discussed in last meeting

Dear Professor,
I hope this email finds you well.

In the last meeting, we discussed about adding non-linearity, explore
convolutions so that the final spike in loss can be expressed as a function
of layer chosen and probability. Please send me the relevant papers so that
I can get some better ideas. Also I want to have weekly/bi-weekly meeting
with you, so that I can get regular feedback. Please let me know how to
proceed.

yours sincerely,
Prasanth

---

Gabriel

headlines: ["Agreement to proceed with Spandan Turing Tests", "Gabriel Kreiman confirms moving on to Turing tests", "Llama3-Spandan Turing Test curation completed and launch proposed"]
anchors: ["final approval", "curation complete", "filtering", "proceed", "reasoning about edits", "double comma cases", "test link", "original intact", "Llama3-Instruct responses", "move on to the Turing tests", "random or nonsensical numbers", "proceed to Turing tests"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Mingzhong Sun <mzsun024@gmail.com>
To: 
  - Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
  - Mengmi Zhang <a0091624@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-05-22T17:31:37+08:00
Subject: Spandan Turing Test

Hi Gabriel and Mengmi,

I've completed the curation of the Llama3-Instruct responses that imitate Spandan, and the Turing Test is now ready to launch at any time.

The only edits I made were the removal of 77 instances of random or nonsensical numbers embedded in the responses. I left all other cases untouched. As mentioned previously, I believe any human intervention in the model’s answers carries risk. At minimum, our edits should never reduce the model’s chances of being selected in the Turing Test. With this in mind, I found removing the “double comma” cases hard to justify because some may interpret such typographical quirks as a more human-like feature, potentially even a clever facet of the model’s design. Overcorrecting these could draw unnecessary scrutiny from reviewers.

With this round of curation complete, I believe we’re ready to proceed. If you both agree, I’ll ask Spandan to share the test link with people he selected. 

(I didn’t include Spandan in this email to avoid such detailed discussion about Turing Test choices influencing his Turing Test performance — he hasn’t started it yet).

Thank you!
---

In fact, I will leave the original intact.

Mengmi

full_content:
Message 1
From: Andrea Capurro <acapurro82@gmail.com>
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-09-02T13:43:06-04:00
Subject: Raíces Este USA - Publicación LinkedIn

Hola Gabriel,


Mi nombre es Andrea Capurro y soy parte de RAÍCES Este USA, es un gusto
saludarte.


Te contacto porque estamos lanzando una serie de publicaciones en LinkedIn
para visibilizar el trabajo de profesionales argentinos/as en esta región.
El objetivo es destacar sus trayectorias y fomentar colaboraciones
científicas y profesionales con Argentina.


Como contexto, las publicaciones serán breve, accesibles y seguirán un
formato estándar, a partir de información pública disponible. El contenido
final será validado por cada profesional y se alternará entre profesionales
en distintas etapas de carrera y ámbitos de trabajo. Seguiremos un
calendario de publicaciones más frecuentes que espera lograr mejor
presencia en redes.


Estoy dando una mano armando el contenido y acá te envío el primer
borrador, que generé con el apoyo de Chat GPT para lograr consistencia. Por
favor, te pido que revises y modifiques todo lo que consideres
necesario (*debe mantenerse
debajo de los 2000 caracteres*), incluyendo links, menciones y hashtags si
resultan incorrectos, desde el google doc
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/15PNZRAdNfUiWDrNP2E17DUFBVa0tVxEnRMJATqNhAL4/edit?usp=sharing>
o en el cuerpo de este email. *De ser posible, antes del 16 de Septiembre. *


Entiendo que diste el OK para compartir tus datos para difusión y explorar
colaboraciones en el Formulario de Inscripción que Aníbal mandó hace unos
meses pero si, por cualquier motivo, preferís que el posteo no se publique,
por favor hacemelo saber. De igual manera, si necesitás más tiempo para
revisar.


Una vez que tengamos el contenido final, te mando la fecha de publicación y
unos tips muy simples para que tenga mejor alcance. Por mientras, si podés:

   - seguí a la Raíces Este-USA (
   https://www.linkedin.com/company/raices-este-usa/) y
   - permití que otros te mencionen (Ir a *Configuración > Visibilidad >
   Permitir menciones con @)*


Mil gracias por tu tiempo y predisposición!


Quedo a disposición por cualquier duda.


Andrea


——

🇦🇷 Conocé al investigador argentino en EE.UU.: Dr. Gabriel Kreiman
🇺🇸 Meet the Argentine researcher in the U.S.: Dr. Gabriel Kreiman

🔬 Neurociencia e inteligencia artificial / Neuroscience & AI
🇦🇷 Investiga cómo el cerebro procesa información visual y cómo se
traducen esos mecanismos a modelos que puedan guiar tecnologías
inteligentes.
🇺🇸 He studies how the brain processes visual information and how those
mechanisms can inspire intelligent technologies.

🎓 Formación / Education
🇦🇷 Licenciado en Química Física por la Universidad de Buenos Aires.
Realizó su maestría y obtuvo su doctorado en California Institute of
Technology (Caltech). Realizó un postdoctorado en el MIT y hoy es profesor
de Oftalmología en Harvard Medical School y Boston Children’s Hospital.
🇺🇸 Graduated in Physical Chemistry from University of Buenos Aires. He
earned his master’s and PhD at the California Institute of Technology
(Caltech). He completed a postdoctoral fellowship at MIT and is now a
Professor of Ophthalmology at Harvard Medical School and Boston Children’s
Hospital.

🌍 Importancia / Relevance
🇦🇷 Su trabajo descifra cómo algunas neuronas en el cerebro humano
representan objetos, rostros y recuerdos —y cómo esos hallazgos inspiran
modelos más claros y potentes de inteligencia artificial.
🇺🇸 His work uncovers how certain neurons in the human brain represent
objects, faces, and memories — insights that inspire clearer and more
robust AI models.

🚀 Lo que viene / What's next
🇦🇷 Avanza en combinar neurofisiología humana con inteligencia artificial,
buscando desarrollar tecnología cognitiva con mayor comprensión del cerebro
real.
🇺🇸 He is advancing the integration of human neurophysiology with
artificial intelligence to develop cognitive technologies that better
reflect real brain function.

🔗 https://klab.tch.harvard.edu/

📍 @University of Buenos Aires @California Institute of Technology @Harvard
Medical School @Boston Children’s Hospital

#MeetTheResearcher #InternationalCollaboration #Neuroscience

📩 ¿Querés colaborar con el Dr. Gabriel Kreiman? Conectate con él o
escribinos.
🌐 @Raices https://raices-este.us/
@Embassy of Argentina in the United States


——

Subject: Fwd: Faculty Dinner Follow-up About Memory Startup

Yesterday, I had a dinner event from a society of undergrad students. They
asked me what I am excited about these days and I briefly mentioned
Memorious. One of the students (who was a student in our Neuro 140 class
last year) approached me and told me that he is working on a memory start
up with other students. He is a junior and we agreed to connect to chat. I
will meet with him and his friends at some point. I can let you know if you
want to join the meeting. I do not really know what they are doing, except
that he said "startup about memory".

Subject: Re: DIA report and Kempner talk abstract

The abstract looks great. You did not send a title, though. You do want a
title when you send it to the Kempner folks.
Also, I would probably add a sentence along the lines of suggesting that
the observation that the model can lead to better human learning suggests
that perhaps it is on the right track as a model of human perception. Or at
the very least, it is not against this notion. But you do not need to add
this if you don't like the point.

Thanks for the DIA report, which I will read and submit.

full_content:
Message 1
From: "Hidalgo, Dianna" <diannahidalgo@g.harvard.edu>
To: Ponce, Carlos Ramon <carlos@hms.harvard.edu>
Time: 2025-02-19T12:23:50-05:00
Subject: Meeting Request to Explore Potential Collaboration on Monkey V1-V4 Data

Dear Carlos,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to reach out regarding a study
we recently submitted to *eLife* on trial-by-trial inter-areal interactions
in the visual cortex. As you know, the paper was accepted for review. We
recently got the reviews, and one of the key reviewer recommendations is to
include data from a second monkey to strengthen the analysis.

The open dataset we used does include a second monkey, but the number of
working V4 electrodes per day is quite limited—especially in the *lights-off
condition*—making it difficult to assess V4→V1 predictability (we don’t
have enough predictive power to model V1, since we only have 9-12
electrodes in V4 for those recording days).

*We were wondering if you might have any monkeys implanted with electrodes
in both V1 and V4* and, if so, whether recording in lights-off conditions
could be a possibility. If this sounds like something worth exploring, we’d
love to set up a quick meeting to discuss potential options.

Would you be open to a chat? Gabriel and I are happy to meet over Zoom or
in person—whatever works best for you.

Looking forward to your thoughts!

Best,
Dianna

---


Message 2
From: "Ponce, Carlos Ramon" <carlos@hms.harvard.edu>
To: Hidalgo, Dianna <diannahidalgo@g.harvard.edu>
Time: 2025-02-19T17:26:17+00:00
Subject: Re: Meeting Request to Explore Potential Collaboration on Monkey
 V1-V4 Data

Yes, we have two monkeys with V1-V4 arrays. Would be happy to help. But we should move fast: monkey C's V1 array has not fared well with time. I'm back on Friday!

reviewer's comments?
Carlos, you do not have to go through all the comments or the whole paper.

that the paper will be published no matter what. But we want to address all
the reviewer's questions as thoroughly as we possibly can. And of course,
you and anyone that contributed with new recordings would be added as
authors.
Let us discuss Friday.

full_content:
Message 1
From: Tomaso Poggio <tp@csail.mit.edu>
To: 
  - Boris Katz <boris@csail.mit.edu>
  - Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-03-18T10:28:32+01:00
Subject: Fwd: CBCM Summer School

She is a grad student of Ila Fiete working in my group. She is good. Let me know what to tell her.

T
Sent from my iPhone

Begin forwarded message:

> From: Qiyao Liang <qiyao@mit.edu>
> Date: March 18, 2025 at 1:45:09 AM GMT+1
> To: tp@csail.mit.edu
> Cc: Kathleen D Sullivan <kdsulliv@mit.edu>
> Subject: CBCM Summer School
> 
> ﻿
> Hi Tommy,
> 
> I hope you've been having a great time on your trip! I’ve been eager to attend the CBCM Summer School for several years now, but I’ve always missed the application deadline. I noticed the deadline is approaching this year, and I wanted to reach out to see if there’s any possibility you could assist with waiving my application, as I understand it’s quite a lengthy process.
> 
> Thank you so much for considering my request!
> 
> Best,

full_content:
Message 1
From: "Pavarino, Elisa Catherine" <epavarino@fas.harvard.edu>
To: gkreiman@gmail.com <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-05-29T15:16:56+00:00
Subject: Urgent clarifications - thanks!

Hi Gabriel,
I hope you're doing well!
As of last night, I have the human-human dataset up to 34 conversations. Only 3 of these are the full 48 exchanges, and at least 4-5 conversations remain incomplete.
Given the time constraints, I'd like to close the dataset at 34 conversations rather than continuing to 50, which would require at least another week of data collection. Since each online participant will only read 32 conversations (with 3 catch trials fixed), I'll need to subsample anyway to extract around 9 human-human conversations. I can ensure one of the three long conversations is included per participant.
Does this approach work for you?
I'm working on launching the study on Prolific by the end of today. However, I need clarification on our submission timeline. Are we still aiming to submit this Saturday (May 31st)? I won't be fully reachable for the next couple of days, so if this creates any issues, I need to adjust my schedule immediately.
To be transparent about expectations: if we maintain the current timeline, we can get results (hopefully!) and basic figures ready. However, for complete results with paper-quality figures, we'd likely need another week to week and a half.
Please let me know the exact submission date so I can plan accordingly.
Thanks, Elisa



---

From: "Pavarino, Elisa Catherine" <epavarino@fas.harvard.edu>

Time: 2025-05-29T16:15:50+00:00
Subject: Re: Urgent clarifications - thanks!

Update - many of the conversations are not downloadable on my end, I get an "internal server error". This might require copying all the conversations by hand, as Singapore is sleeping now. This will set us back on time. I feel really bad to say this, trust me, but if we could get another extension, I think that is the best possible scenario.

Elisa

for Brains, Minds and Machines. He received his M.Sc. and Ph.D. from

award and NIH New Innovator award. His research focuses on computational
neuroscience and AI approaches to learning and memory.

Message 1

To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-06-04T16:45:14-04:00
Subject: SFN 2025- Should I apply to present Aim1?

Hi Gabriel,

I hope the traveling to Boston is going well. I saw that the SFN abstract
submission deadline is now tomorrow, Thursday June 5th at 5pm. I was
wondering if you thought it was a good idea to present Aim1? It would be my
last year attending as a grad student?

I have an old abstract that I submitted for the kemper in neuroscience for
your reference.

Understanding how hierarchical processing, maturation, and robustness
emerge in the primate visual system is a central challenge in neuroscience.
Directly studying these processes in biological neural circuits remains
difficult due to current technological limitations. Here, we use deep
convolutional neural networks (DCNNs) as biologically inspired models of
the primate visual system, leveraging their accessible connectivity
patterns, activations, and performance metrics to generate concrete,
experimentally testable predictions about cortical function.
   We investigate three biological hypotheses using DCNNs: (1) hierarchical
maturation of visual areas during development, (2) structured changes in
network representations during learning new visual tasks (plasticity), and
(3) robustness differences across cortical areas when facing synaptic or
neuronal perturbations. Our findings reveal that hierarchical maturation
emerges naturally in DCNNs, with earlier visual layers maturing faster than
later ones—consistent with developmental patterns observed in primates.
Furthermore, during transfer learning, higher layers adapt more readily to
new tasks, suggesting a hierarchical structure in visual cortical
plasticity. Finally, robustness tests demonstrate that higher-level
representations in strictly feedforward architectures (e.g., AlexNet) are
significantly more resilient to synaptic and node perturbations compared to
lower layers, whereas architectures with skip connections (e.g., ResNet)
show robustness dependent on circuit connectivity rather than strict
hierarchical depth.
   These findings hold consistently across multiple datasets and training
methods, including alternative biologically plausible training schemes such
as forward direct feedback alignment (FDFA). By bridging biological theory
and deep learning, our results propose testable predictions about visual
cortical development, learning, and robustness, guiding future experimental
approaches in NeuroAI research.


Let me know your thoughts?
Best,
Dianna

full_content:
Message 1
From: "Hidalgo, Dianna" <diannahidalgo@g.harvard.edu>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-04-29T06:36:18-04:00
Subject: Today AMA for neuro 140/240. Do we order pizza?

Dear Gabriel,

Apologies for last minute email. Would you like me to order pizza today? I
can have it be there at 330pm? For how many people you think?


I have to attend a presentation in HMS for PiNBAC so I won’t be there right
at 3pm but I can be there at 330pm. I can get another TA though to be there.


Best,
Dianna

---

Time: 2025-04-29T06:43:39-04:00
Subject: Re: Today AMA for neuro 140/240. Do we order pizza?

It would be great to order pizza. 3:30pm would be great. If you do, please
announce it to all the students asap so that people show up.
Based on the previous lectures, I think that we have had around 50-60
students show up. Not sure that everybody will eat. Let's say pizza for
40-50 students, would that make sense?

headlines: ["Gabriel confirms oversubscribed round and agrees to July 15 meeting", "Gabriel informs Lucas that Memorious fundraising round closed led by Mayfield Fund", "Gabriel requests to move July 15 Memorious\u2013Coatue meeting due to travel", "Gabriel shares scheduling link with Hadley to set up Memorious\u2013Coatue meeting", "Hadley proposes specific July 22 time windows for rescheduled meeting", "Hari introduces Memorious team to Lucas and shares overview deck", "Lucas asks Hadley to find time for a meeting with Memorious", "Lucas congratulates Gabriel and expresses interest in next fundraising round", "Original Memorious\u2013Coatue meeting canceled and rescheduled to July 15"]

full_content:
Message 1
From: Hari Narayanan <harinarayanan2001@gmail.com>
To: 
  - Lucas Swisher <lswisher@coatue.com>
  - Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
  - Spandan Madan <spandan.madan@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-06-18T12:59:23-05:00
Subject: Memorious <> Lucas (Coatue)

Hi Lucas,

As promised, I’m writing to connect you with the Memorious team.

Memorious <https://memorious.io/>was co-founded by Professor Gabriel
Kreiman, a leading authority on computational neuroscience, along with his
student Spandan Madan. They’re building a personal “memorome”—a structured,
searchable interface for your life’s memories—grounded in cutting-edge
neuroscience and AI research from the Kreiman lab. On a personal note,
Professor Kreiman was my senior thesis advisor at Harvard, so I’m
especially excited to make the intro!

Professor Kreiman—Lucas leads the growth investing strategy at Coatue, one
of the world’s premier technology investment firms with deep expertise in
AI and product-led growth (longtime backers of companies like OpenAI and
Glean). He’s an exceptional investor, and I really admire the way he thinks
about businesses. I'm confident you’ll enjoy the conversation.

Attaching their overview deck—hope this sparks something exciting!

Best,
Hari

---

From: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
To: Lucas Swisher <lswisher@coatue.com>
Time: 2025-07-26T19:09:30-04:00
Subject: Re: Memorious <> Lucas (Coatue)

Dear Lucas,

We wanted to give you a quick update on our fundraising. We’re excited to
share that the round ended up being led by Mayfield Fund. We were ~3x
oversubscribed for our initial $2.5M target, and after navigating
allocation and ownership dynamics, we ultimately raised $3M on a $15M SAFE.

We are sorry that the timing did not work out this time, but we hope that
you will be joining our journey in the next fundraising round. We would be
happy to connect and tell you more about Memorious. We are going to be
moving to the Bay area, and we would love to keep in touch as we move
forward with Memorious.
[...]

full_content:
Message 1
From: Jenni Goodman <jenni@underscore.vc>
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-05-02T14:28:53-04:00
Subject: Invite: Underscore + Gunderson Lunch and Learn - May 15th

Hi Gabriel,


I hope you’re doing well! I’d like to invite you to a Lunch and Learn we’re
hosting with Gunderson on May 15th. The topic for this session is *Mastering
the Term Sheet*.

Whether you’re preparing for your first fundraise or want to better
understand the terms you’re likely to encounter, this session will cover
the key elements every founder should know—from valuation and liquidation
preferences to board structure and more.


Learn more and RSVP here
<https://event.underscore.vc/underscore-vc/rsvp/invite?e=lunch-and-learn-with-gunderson&inviteId=tyFUB5fKiZxV7q1svBVnsS>.
Hope to see you there!


Best,

Jenni Goodman

Director of Community | She/Her | Underscore VC

45 School St
<https://gatsby.events/links?t3=eyJpIjoiODcxM2VlMmQtYjJkNC00ZDcwLWI4NDUtZTdmY2U0Y2VjOGZkIiwidSI6Imh0dHBzOi8vbWFwcy5nb29nbGUuY29tLz9xPTQ1K1NjaG9vbCtTdCZlbnRyeT1nbWFpbCZzb3VyY2U9ZyJ9&e3=eyJlbnQiOiI2NTMzZDQ5NS02YTRkLTQ1ODItYmRmNS0yZjljMTMzM2MwNjAiLCJlbSI6IjBhNjQyMTJmLTkyY2MtNDU1NC1hNDMyLTU3MDgyODlkNjkyNCJ9>

Message 1
From: Sarah Dundulis <sdundulis@mbl.edu>
To: Boris Katz <boris@csail.mit.edu>
Time: 2025-06-21T00:08:52+00:00
Subject: Re: Any pending grants

Hi  Boris, Andre, and Gabirel

You still must report this under pending awards till you hear that it is funded or not funded. The only pending award you do not add is the NIH one being considered.   NIH is severely scrutinizing Other Support documents and so we have to make sure we are reporting everything I would even run it by your AOR/Office of Sponsored programs.

On you OS you must please

  *   Put any pending grants you also must include the project number or grant number in the details
  *   Under” In Kind” if there are not  “In Kind” awards please put None or N/A
  *   Gabriel – you seem to have one active award that was not included, and we have to remove the pending award that was not funded
  *   Then please sign and send back to me, they would like this by end of day Monday.
Thank you,
Sarah

From: Boris Katz <boris@csail.mit.edu>
Date: Friday, June 20, 2025 at 6:31 PM
To: Sarah Dundulis <sdundulis@mbl.edu>
Cc: Andrei Barbu <abarbu@csail.mit.edu>, boris <boris@csail.mit.edu>
Subject: Re: Any pending grants
Hi Sarah,

I just looked at the proposals we submitted in the past year and realized that around the same time we submitted this NIH proposal, we also submitted an NSF proposal as a sub to the University of Virginia. However, we haven’t received any response from the NSF.

Here is the information about the proposal, in which Andrei was also a co-PI:

* Title: Collaborative Research: Improving Multimodal Knowledge Retention with Theory of Mind
*Major Goals: The goal of this project is to control the forgetting curve — the phenomenon that we lose knowledge exponentially, and to avoid doing so, we must refresh it at regular, increasing intervals. With modern machine learning and new techniques that weave together theory of mind with vision, language, audio, social interactions, robotics, and storytelling, we intend to turn the shape of this curve from exponential to linear, determine its parameters per student, and predict which interventions optimize its parameters for every learner.
*Status of Support: Pending
Name of PD/PI: Boris Katz
*Source of Support: NSF
*Primary Place of Performance: MIT
Project/Proposal Start and End Date: (MM/YYYY) (if available): 042026 - 03/2028
* Total Award Amount (including Indirect Costs): $900,000
* Person Months per budget period Devoted to the Proposal/Active Project:
Year (YYYY)
Person Months (##.##)
1.   2025
1.2
2.   2026
1.2
3.   2027
1.2
4.   2028
1.2

Thank you.

Boris



On Jun 20, 2025, at 2:15 PM, Sarah Dundulis <sdundulis@mbl.edu> wrote:

Hi Andrei and Boris

Besides this NIH pending proposal for BMM,  do you have any other pending proposals that were not disclosed in your NIH Other support that was submitted to NIDA ?

Thank you,
Sarah

Hi Gabirel

Sorry I misspoke you have an active award on your Other Support Document that is missing a project number. I put the award they are referring to below. “Project number” should show up under Status of support as it does on your other award on the document.   So on your Other Support Document you could:

  *   please remove the pending proposal that was not funded
  *   add the project number in under the Towards a Biophysical model proposal , PDF, flatten, and send it back to me I will submit it with the other revised OS documents.
  *   Under “In Kind”  write NONE or N/A if you have none.  (I am sorry they are really scrutinizing these documents – having to add None under In Kind isn’t even in the guidance for this document).
  *   Please PDF, certify sign, flatten and send back to me to submit to NIH.


*Title: Towards a biophysical model of neurophysiological signatures incorporating cell types, transcriptomics,

and morphology

*Major Goals: This proposal aims to build biophysically detailed models of neuronal circuits based on gene

expression profiles, cellular morphology information, neuronal connectivity and different cellular types.

*Status of Support: Active

*Source of Support: NIH

*Primary Place of Performance: Boston Children’s Hospital, Boston, USA

Message 1
From: "Hidalgo, Dianna" <diannahidalgo@g.harvard.edu>
To: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-09-13T19:38:35-04:00
Subject: Aim1 slides for Carlos + Dianna + Gabriel - anything else I could
 add/remove for Monday presentation

Dear Gabriel,

I hope this email finds you well. I am working on the slides for our
meeting coming up on Monday Sep 15th  with Carlos, and wanted to share my
draft so far. I'm still working on animations, and some typos, but wanted
to run the content by you to see if you have any suggestions on what I
could add/remove or clarify. If you have the time, otherwise no worries!


Here is the link
<https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1y2TWQXXqx1TwrxiSwqKSDEmR1Ev5UWidsT2UtY3kQXg/edit?usp=sharing>
to the draft.

Thank you and will see you in two days!
Dianna

---
Here is the [link](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1y2TWQXXqx1TwrxiSwqKSDEmR1Ev5UWidsT2UtY3kQXg/edit?usp=sharing) to the draft. 
  

Thank you and will see you in two days!
Dianna


Message 2
From: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
To: Hidalgo, Dianna <diannahidalgo@g.harvard.edu>
Time: 2025-09-13T22:42:01-04:00
Subject: Re: Aim1 slides for Carlos + Dianna + Gabriel - anything else I could
 add/remove for Monday presentation

These slides are great and will be useful for your presentations.
For Monday, no need for animations.

I suggest the structure that I wrote about in the piece of paper that I
sent you.
1. Robustness to neuronal death + Theory of linear networks
2. Development.
3. Learning.
It would be great to also discuss the connections to Neuroscience and
specifically, if we can compare to measurements from recordings in V1, V2,
V4.










On Sat, Sep 13, 2025 at 7:38 PM Hidalgo, Dianna <diannahidalgo@g.harvard.edu>
wrote:

>
>

--

points in all the additional questions that we could use as jumping points
also. I will share the slides with Carlos now.

Thank you again!
Dianna

Hi Professor, Spandan,

It was great catching up today—and Spandan, really nice to meet you!

You're both building a really compelling product—it was fascinating to
learn more about Memorious. I’ll keep an eye out for the overview deck you

introductions.

Hari

Message 7
From: Gabriel Kreiman <gkreiman@gmail.com>
To: Hari Narayanan <harinarayanan2001@gmail.com>
Time: 2025-06-24T09:37:20-04:00
Subject: Re: Great Speaking Today

Hello Hari,

First, thank you so much for all the introductions. We really appreciate
it.

Second, just to update you, we are currently oversubscribed in our first
round of fundraising and we are trying to figure out how we want to proceed
(raise more, increase cap, just say no to several people who wanted to
invest, etc).

Third, in terms of a16z, they invested in two companies that are somewhat
competitors. We are wondering whether there is a conflict of interest or
not .We really like a16z, we are just wondering what the best strategy is
for us. These companies are not strictly competitors but they are somewhat
close to what we do. Any thoughts on this?

To answer the questions from your friend:
Memorious will revolutionize how we interact with data. Instead of users
chasing data, data will proactively come to you, where you need it and when
you need it. We are eliminating search and prompts. This is a key
distinction with companies that merely record and store data, or companies
that are simply summarizing meetings, etc.
Memorious has two key products. (1) Memory-as-a-Service through an API
where enterprises can directly use our algorithms so that their employees
or users can proactively and directly access all their memories and data.
(2) A stand-alone app on the phone for users to augment their cognition and
become superhuman via perfect and infinite memory.

Thanks again for all your help!

Subject: Re: Great Speaking Today

Hi Professor,

Great to hear about the success with the fundraising! I’m happy to be a
sounding board as you navigate the funding questions. I also think the
folks at Prod might have some valuable suggestions on that front.

Regarding a16z, it’s definitely worth considering whether a partnership
makes sense given their investments in competitors. In some cases, that can
be a positive if they bring deep knowledge of the market and can connect
you with customers or talent. However, if that’s not the case, it might be
worth holding off on a partnership for now, especially considering the
overlap and potential conflict of interest. The degree of overlap matters
here, particularly since you have other strong funding sources lined up. I
hope your meeting with them tomorrow goes well—I'd recommend really probing
their expertise and network in this space.

As for ongoing conversations, the great thing about all the firms (Sequoia,
Coatue, Greenoaks, a16z) is their ability to invest at all stages, from
seed through growth to IPO and beyond. I think it’s always beneficial to
have these conversations and build relationships over time, even if just a
warm intro/no immediate transaction. If they do invest down the line, their
name/stamp of approval can often unlock revenue and partnership
opportunities. At the very least, they tend to have great connections and
are often willing to provide excellent advice for free.

Thanks for the blurb on Memorious! Super helpful and makes a lot of sense.

Please don’t hesitate to reach out if I can help in any other way. Really
rooting for you and Spandan here!

Best,
Hari
